Hi G,

You can switch from the cdn in a few straightforward steps.
1. Download jquery to `haste-server/static/`
2. Edit `static/index.html` so that it points at your local jquery rather than google.
3. Restart haste-server.

Using a cdn here is helpful to prevent duplication of code and to reduce the small amount of bandwidth serving assets when self hosting. 

All the best, 
Bryce

If this response is helpful to you and resolves your problem please close out this issue. I'm not affiliated with this project but wanted to help out where I could.
Copying jquery directly in the static folder isn't a very good idea, I think it would be better if we include it with npm (https://www.npmjs.com/package/jquery)
I've started a new pull request here: #375

Updates for clarity:
I cloned the repo and ran `docker-compose up --build`
Open the page in FireFox.
With inspector open I hit save and a 500 error is returned back to the browser and the server logs `verbose: error adding document`

I took a little bit of time and did some debugging output with winston on the memcached document store library. That gave me an error that it expected a number but was getting a string for the expiration.

Looking back through the commits the docker-entrypoint.js was changed in commit 36c854ef1bdc3305c8f10c55688c137e6bb5e8c4 
This commit creates a javascript object after doing a destructuring assignment on process.env
This makes every data type in the config and storage objects a string because it carries over the string type from process.env attributes.

By adding explicit conversions using Number() I ensure the values in the config.js are numbers as well and then the memcache default build works successfully when re-run using `docker-compose up --build`

HTTP Error Code 503 aka "Service unavailable" indicates a server problem you cannot do anything about. Error codes starting with 500 are server-side while error codes starting with 400 are usually client-side.

I use mongo as storage type

According to https://github.com/seejohnrun/haste-server#mongodb:
> You can also set an expire option to the number of seconds to expire keys in. This is off by default, but will constantly kick back expirations on each view or post.

From what it sounds like, you have to include the following in your `config.json`:
```json
{
  "type": "mongodb",
  "connectionUrl": "mongodb://localhost:27017/database",
  "expire": 2592000
}
```
What I set in the `expire` field was 2592000 seconds which is 30 days, just as you requested. A reminder that this is from the last view date and not from the creation date.

Lastly, if this issue seems to have solved your problem, please remember to close the issue.

This is good feature

Currently, that depends on the storage method.
For `file`, you can navigate to the specified directory (`./data` by default) and search the files for the content to identify the one you want to delete. You could also generate the md5 sum of the document key in the URL to get the file name (but I expect that to depend on the exact algorithm).
For any of the other storage methods you can basically do the same thing for the respective store.

That being said, I would welcome a feature to delete or edit documents from the UI. Is anything like that planned?
I'm thinking a key to prove ownership that would be generated and displayed after creation. That way there'd be no need for authentication while still enabling authorization.
Integrating the client would require some more thought, since I wouldn't want to copy the "admin access" URL by default but also not "lose" it.

I wouldn't mind working on that or a similar solution, but I didn't want to start without first checking if that's even part of the vision.

I just did:

```bash
npm install memcached
```

and the service started. However, I'm running into other issues where I can't save anything.

If you open up config.js and scroll down to "storage", change that to the following:

` 
"storage": {
    "type": "file",
    "path": "./hastes"
  },
`

It will then save the "hastes" to a folder titled "hastes" in plain text documents, your server will start right up without an issue!


Obviously still run `NPM Install` and start with **NPM start**. Only downfall with this configuration is your "hastes" will not automatically delete. 

If youre **STILL** getting errors run `NPM audit fix` followed by `NPM install` and finally `NPM start`

With this, having the option for logins and being able to set it so only people with accounts can make pastes would go a long way to make this the best self hosted paste bin

The issue with this is that this needs accounts, which is what hastebin isn't. Having to log in adds time and effort to a service designed for quick sharing. If you did it by IP, people would spoof and could edit any post using the API

If it's done like pastebin logins, you can allow the system administraor to 
Enable / disable account registration
Enable / disable guest paste creation

And allow the person creating the paste to select if the paste they are sharing is viewable to the general public (via the link key) or would need to be a registered user to view.
By default, set it so all pastes shared are shared publicly (so any user who doesn't have an account can still read said shared paste, but just cant create their own if the system admin turned that off)

```
npm install memcached
```

After reading the packages that are imported into this project say that it's milliseconds but seems weird that the default would be a minute and 26 seconds.

@chamunks the max age for the cache control header should be in seconds. `86400` is 1 day (`86400 / 60 / 60`).

I don't believe anywhere in the documentation it states 30 minutes. That sounds similar to the number in the config mentioned in the `about.md` on https://hastebin.com which is a different number than this one:

* `staticMaxAge` is the cache control value for static assets (ie: `about.md`) for browser caching (see https://www.keycdn.com/blog/http-cache-headers/)
* `expires` is the amount of time before a given key should expire automatically

I'm happy to make a change to the README for more clarity but will wait on your response before doing so!

I've recently merged a PR for a Dockerfile, so I'm going to close this for now

I use a simple Dockerfile:

```
FROM node:slim

COPY . /usr/src/app
WORKDIR /usr/src/app
RUN npm install
CMD ./start-haste.sh
EXPOSE 7777
```

The start-haste.sh can also be omitted.  It just sets REDIS for our deployment:
```
#!/bin/bash

export REDISTOGO_URL=$REDIS_PORT
node server.js
```

It seems like he is asking for a custom key value rather than a sub-domain - similar to url-shortener services.  For my $.02, since hastebin expires data by default, I don't see much benefit in adding this feature.  In fact, I want to discourage people in my workspace from treating hastebin as though the data will be persistently available.  To be clear, I'm talking of my own deployment and not the hastebin.com offering, but I would be concerned that this feature might communicate an implied availability level for the posted data.

Ah okay - I've been trying to avoid adding custom key names because I think it crowds the interface having to (or allowing) adding more detail to a paste at creation time.

Why was this closed? I think that this is a good idea for web devs to interact with hastebin in their site.

The implementation is more complicated than just adding a header on the post handler. Other routes need it too, and you have to implement a response to potential [preflight requests](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTTP/CORS#Preflighted_requests) to properly support CORS.

I realised all of this after opening the PR. It was closed because the issues above weren't addressed.

> I think that this is a good idea for web devs to interact with hastebin in their site.

I still agree. The initial PR was prompted by GitHub's decision to [no longer support anonymous gists](https://blog.github.com/2018-02-18-deprecation-notice-removing-anonymous-gist-creation/), of which I know there were a number of applications using the API + CORS.

I just made a docker container and everything seems to work when I added CORS to all the headers. It might be redundant, but it does get the job done. Here is what document_handler.js looks like: https://github.com/InnovativeInventor/docker-haste/blob/master/document_handler.js.

Looking at the config.js in this repo, looks like I just have to throw the expire property to the storage block, so I did so.
```
  "storage": {
    "path": "./data","type": "file",
    "expire": 31536000

Could the `expire` property be added to the README? I see that the different storing methods have a notion about the `expire` but it is not really described for the regular file storage option

@C0rn3j `expire` does not work with file storage currently.  We don't have a separate store where the expiration would be placed - and currently don't serialize them into the stored file.  Could be a great idea for an enhancement if people want similar.

>`expire` does not work with file storage currently.

Hey :)
Got pinged from the other thread, figured I'd try to help out here
Not too familiar with the structure of this project but I had a look at `application.js` and everything there looked fine. I debugged the `hljs` function that gets called with the `cs` language and found a masked exception:

    Error: Illegal lexeme "<" for mode "<unnamed>"
        at m (highlight.min.js:formatted:248)
        at Object.l [as highlight] (highlight.min.js:formatted:267)
        at Object.success (application.min.js:formatted:21)
        at n (jquery.min.js:2)
        at Object.fireWith [as resolveWith] (jquery.min.js:2)
        at w (jquery.min.js:4)
        at XMLHttpRequest.d (jquery.min.js:4)

Turns out the version of `hljs` this project depends on doesn't like classes that extend from generic parents. Specifically if I change `Comparer<Fraction>` on line 46 to `Comparer` everything seems to highlight just fine! Check it out: https://hastebin.com/gazufepaso.cs

I also checked out the `hljs` repo and looks like there's already an issue open there for this problem, go +1 it https://github.com/isagalaev/highlight.js/issues/1424

Hope this helped

@KingDuckZ @doodadjs I think the requirement to use a proxy server is an issue.  I'd prefer if we could get a solution that would for the server-side as well.  The issue there is that there's currently no data passed between the two layers.  I've started on a branch to do this, but I'm not ready to merge it yet.  If someone else is interested it shouldn't be too difficult to get going, but I don't want to bring in a feature (as much as I appreciate the work here) that's half complete.

Otherwise, I'd be down to take a look this weekend and try to get something that works for both cases.
@seejohnrun I understand. I wanted to touch less code than possible, but that's not enough.
This works so well for me while proxying via Nginx and I think would be beneficial for others.

You should always deploy applications behind a reverse proxy in production - it allows the use of HTTPS, ratelimiting, caching, and fail2ban.

People who don't want to use reverse proxy can just not use a base URL. There's no need to use a base URL if you don't have a reverse proxy, because there is nothing else you can serve

I know how to fix! You missed charset declaration! That fixing when I toggling my charset from Cyrillic-1251 into UTF-8. In result, undeclared charset causes wired result on parsing of script which contains some special characters being detected wrongly because charset missmatch.

One of fixes is HTTP-header:

```
Content-Type: text/html; charset=utf-8
```

which must be sent before sending actual data
Check closed issue number #75

I don't like this kind of "implicit magic". It's a guarantee for weird, unpredictable behavior (to those not knowing about the trick). There might be cases where you would _want_ to receive the html would have to modify your user agent to do so.

If you want to download the actual file, just feed the RAW url.

IMO it makes a lot of sense to do this, feels pretty natural as well (again, IMO :smile:). I also can't think of a single reason one would want to fetch the HTML output seeing as the paste data is not included in that response at all.

edit: Not sure how this creates weird behavior - I think it's pretty clear? The unpredictability of receiving different responses depending on the user agent is only an issue when people want to fetch the HTML content using these agents, which doesn't make sense in the first place.

It would be interesting to traverse request logs to see how often these user agents hit the non-raw endpoint. Most of these probably wanted the raw output - hence this PR.

As of now, there is no option to specify the config file via system arguments. It needs to be defined in `server.js`. You could manually set the path of your new `config.js` by defining it in `server.js`. I doubt that this will be added; do you have a use-case that may shed light on it's validity?

I was trying to figure out how to streamline the deployment and it just didn't make sense to place the config file in the same dir with the code. Then again, I'm not familiar with deploying npm-based things. I've settled for putting everything somewhere in `/opt/` and managing the whole thing with ansible.

The real use-case would be: how do I package haste-server (apt,rpm,pacman)? I haven't bothered looking into other npm software to see how it is packaged but I'm guessing that not being able to specify the configuration in any other way would be a problem.

npm packages are simple; all you need to do is create a `package.json` using `npm init` and specify the  repository's url, it will take care of the rest. Have a look at https://docs.npmjs.com/getting-started/using-a-package.json.

You could write an init script(or systemd equivalent). Make sure to specify the exact steps; i.e. redis-server on default port for example, npm start. connect `1.9.2` is requiring `qs >=0.4.0`, which means _anything_ greater than `0.4.0`.  This is pulling in the very latest `qs` which is `6.0.0` and requires npm `v4.0.0` or greater.  Fixing this locally would either require a patch to that very old version of connect, or you can try installing an older version of `qs` before you install `connect` locally.

The issue seems to be that multi-line coomments are matched in a single <span> element that spans multiple lines. However, any preceding text in the same "row" as the multi-line span gets aligned on the bottom and not on the top. Here is a screenshot that illustrates the issue:

![2015-02-28_17 35 32](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/931051/6426908/b2831fb2-bf70-11e4-9d12-c1e1c6cf7b5c.png)

This can be fixed by removing the `display: inline-block` definition. [Not `vertical-align: top` because that would still misaling any leading spaces after the newlines!]

For some reason there is also a `line-height: 1em` override, which causes multi-line comments to offset the line numbering because a line in the comment span has a lower height than a normal line in the code block.
This has been fixed in a recent version of HLJS it seems / updated now in prod. Thank you!

This is a weird one, but it's actually as a result of how winston's levels work(ed?).

Thanks for the reply! Indeed, levels are messed up in winston config files, and it's not fixed yet in my version. Unfortunately, re-ordering said levels manually (so the "debug" level will be lowest priority, zero) didn't help me. I found a workaround with _forever_, which allows console logs to be piped directly into a file (and in a handy plaintext format). It's also a nice wrapper for launching multiple node instances. Now I launch haste-server like this: 
forever -a -l /var/log/haste.log
My config.js for haste-server looks like this now: 
  "logging": [                                                                            
    {                                                                                     
      "type": "Console",
      "level": "debug",
      "timestamp": true
    }                                                                                     
  ],
This solution is adding another layer of complexity (forever), but at least it does the job.

To enable IPv6 I don't think you need any changes to server.js. Just modify the config.json host to use the IPv6 version of the address:

``` json
{
"host": "::1",
"port": 7777
}
```

I think the brackets you were using around the IPv6 version of the address were causing the errors.

Just adding a comment to this old question: 

You can send the stdout of something to hastebin like this:

    somecommand | curl --data-binary@- https://hastebin.com/documents

That will return a JSON repsonse that looks something like:

    {"key":"oxekofidik"}

And you can turn that into a URL by appending the value to `https://hastebin.com`.  That is, the URL for this example would be <https://hastebin.com/oxekofidik>. This is an unfortunate api, because it makes hastebin difficult to use from the command line with some code to handle extracting the key from the response and generate a URL.

A simple shell script that handles this might look like:

```
#!/bin/bash

result=$(curl -sf --data-binary @${1:--} https://hastebin.com/documents) || {
	echo "ERROR: failed to post document" >&2
	exit 1
}

key=$(jq -r .key <<< $result)

echo "https://hastebin.com/${key}"

```

Assuming the script is named `hastebin`, running it looks like:

```
$ echo look ma no hands | hastebin
https://hastebin.com/lubiveyuni

```
Or:

```
$ hastebin README.md 
https://hastebin.com/carateheki

```

---

It would be useful if hastebin were to implement support for the http `PUT` method at this endpoint, and then return a URL.  This would allow convenient use of curl's `-T` command line option without any additional wrapper.  Posting a file would look like:

    curl -Tmyfile https://hastebin.com/documents

And posting stdin would look like:

    curl -T- https://hastebin.com/documents

It would also make sense to implement the api on `/` instead of `/documents`, because this would reduce the amount of typing by 25%.  Support posting over plain `http://` and you could just write:

    curl -T- hastebin.com

Which would be awesome, and is short enough that it doesn't really make sense to write a dedicated client anymore.  In fact, [chunk.io](http://chunk.io) does exactly this, and it is super convenient.

As it turns out: it works.

I patched it but the patch didn't go down the way it should.

On the client side the subdirectory becomes part of the key that is used to handle the file. So instead of "$key" you get something like "subdirectory/$key" which is kinda annoying and can only be fixed by changing the routes in the main server. They have to be change anyway to support "$subdir/$key" but in the end they need to support "$subdir/$subdir/$key" because of the mess that happens on the client side.

It's also a problem to get the new subfolder to the client part without patching stuff. I had to patch the application.js file to make the requests go to the right place.

So far it doesn't seem easy to just add a root_path variable.

Any hints or tips that could help me to implement it and I'm offering the patch :)

KR,

G.

I found some [initscript here](https://gist.github.com/Aricg/5032312#file-node_debian_init-sh) that I edited for a Debian host (I've not done an Arch Linux initscrip yet).

``` bash
#!/bin/bash

### BEGIN INIT INFO
# Provides:          hastebin
# Required-Start:    $local_fs $remote_fs $network $syslog $redis_server
# Required-Stop:     $local_fs $remote_fs $network $syslog $redis_server
# Default-Start:     2 3 4 5
# Default-Stop:      0 1 6
# Short-Description: starts hastebin
# Description:       starts hastebin
### END INIT INFO

PATH=/sbin:/usr/sbin:/bin:/usr/bin:/usr/local/bin:/opt/node/bin # modify if you need
DAEMON_ARGS="/home/hastebin/haste-server/server.js" # path to your node.js server/app
DESC="node.js pastebin server" # whatever fancy description you like
NODEUSER=hastebin:hastebin # USER who OWNS the daemon process (no matter whoever runs the init script)
LOCAL_VAR_RUN=/var/run # in case the init script is run by non-root user, you need to
NAME=node # name of the node.js executable
DAEMON=/opt/node/bin/$NAME # this SHOULD POINT TO where your node executable is

(...)
```

Then :

```
~ # update-rc.d hastebin defaults
```

<VirtualHost *:80>

In that case, we'd still end up with multiple `EXDATE` entries, so I'm torn on the value here. Is there somewhere that'd having trouble parsing these as-is?

Oo, this is where my lack of familiarity with the spec shows. If I've interpreted this snippet correctly:
> The "DTSTART" property defines the first instance in the recurrence set.  The "DTSTART" property value SHOULD match the pattern of the recurrence rule, if specified.  The recurrence set generated with a "DTSTART" property value that doesn't match the pattern of the rule is undefined.  The final recurrence set is generated by gathering all of the start DATE-TIME values generated by any of the specified "RRULE" and "RDATE" properties, and then excluding any start DATE-TIME values specified by "EXDATE" properties.

It sounds like there should be alignment between the type of value for DTSTART, the values generated by RRULE, and the values listed in EXDATE. Which might suggest that EXDATE values should share the same time zone as DTSTART (be it UTC, local/floating, or specified with a TZID).

However, looking closely at the wording used in the last sentence of that excerpt:
> and then excluding any start DATE-TIME values specified by "EXDATE" **_properties_**

Is that sufficient evidence to suggest that multiple EXDATE properties are permitted?
This has been fixed now, thank you!

I am also experiencing this bug, except on Danish daylight savings time change on March 31st, 2019. I can confirm downgrading to `0.16.2` resolves this specific issue. It definitely seems to be related to DST.

Please find 2 examples below that replicate the issue.

## First example
In our case, we have a daily task to be executed at 8am. If the schedule is created to start on `2019-03-31`, no occurrence is created for the 31st.

```ruby
Time.zone = "Copenhagen"

starts_at = Time.zone.parse("2019-03-31 00:00:00 CET")
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(starts_at) do |s|
  s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.hour_of_day(8)
end

schedule.first(2)
# =>  [Mon, 01 Apr 2019 08:00:00 CEST +02:00, Tue, 02 Apr 2019 08:00:00 CEST +02:00]
```

I would expect the first element of the above array to be `Sun, 31 Mar 2019 08:00:00 CEST +02:00`, (`2019-03-31T08:00:00+02:00` in iso8601).

## Second example

Interestingly enough, if you start the schedule the day before, the desired occurrence on the 31st appears, i.e.

```ruby
starts_at = Time.zone.parse("2019-03-30 00:00:00 CET")

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(starts_at) do |s|
  s.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.hour_of_day(8)
end

schedule.first(2)
# => [Sat, 30 Mar 2019 08:00:00 CET +01:00, Sun, 31 Mar 2019 08:00:00 CEST +02:00]
```

Hope this helps!

I think the relevant issue for that align method is #416, which was intended to minimize the possibility of creating invalid rule combinations with different frequencies/multiples.

No worries! I appreciate the help as I'm pretty new to the internals of this gem.

My understanding is that `hour_of_day` was running into issues due to referencing `base_interval_validation`.

Using the PR spec as an example, `base_interval_validation` is `#<IceCube::Validations::WeeklyInterval::Validation:0x007f8508307610 @interval=2, @week_start=:sunday>`

This causes [L28](https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/validations/hour_of_day.rb#L28) to subtract 2 (weeks) from 11 (hours) without their respective units.

The `minute_of_hour` and `second_of_minute` do not seem to reference `base_interval_validation` at all, instead using `validations[:minute_of_hour]` and `validations[:second_of_minute]`. I don't see opportunity for the same unit mismatching.


I share your concerns though as to whether this is a partial solution. I would have to research to see whether there could be a situation where `@validations[:interval]` could contain both weekly and hourly interval validations. We may still need to extract the hourly interval in this case. Additionally [here](https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/rules/weekly_rule.rb#L54) there is potential for interval unit mismatch (although I do not have context to know whether externalities already prevent this).

Hi Jacob,

Can you say more about your "128 checks"? Are you checking the same date against 128 different schedules, or 128 dates against the same schedule?

I'm not seeing the same performance that you reported. With the above benchmark running on ruby 2.5, and ActiveSupport 5.2, I'm seeing:

```
       user     system      total        real
   0.128318   0.009283   0.137601 (  0.145315)
```

A couple things to consider anyway:

First, if you can fast-forward your start date so there are fewer days in the past to consider, that should reduce the time linearly. I see you are evaluating over 3 years there, which is some 1100 days that it works through. You might be able to load your earliest `previous_occurrence` once, and then use that as your new start time for the following checks:

```
check_dates = [Date.new(2018, 6, 16), Date.new(2019, 7, 17)]
check_dates.sort.each do |date|
  result = schedule.previous_occurrence(date)
  schedule.start_time = result # fast-forward new start time for the next item
end
```

Second, `previous_occurrence` is much less performant because it needs to enumerate from the start time. The way IceCube works is by jumping forward the smallest interval from the schedule (daily in your example), and selecting matching occurrences. `next_occurrence` is just one jump forward. If you can use that, it's another possibility instead of advancing the schedule start time.

Finally, I'm not sure if your daily rule is an artificial example, but if your schedule is really just "every day" then you don't really need the complexity that IceCube provides, and you could just use much simpler `date - 1` arithmetic for your use case instead.

The smallest unit that IceCube works with is 1 second: milliseconds are dropped.

I think here because you are trying to jump from `00:00:00` to the previous occurrence at `23:59:59.99999`, it's jumping back to `23:59:59` which is before the range of the schedule.

I think we are not normalizing the start time when we check that boundary: looks like an edge case.

:wave: @danielvlopes What you're looking for is `day`.  There are actually two ways to accomplish this, maybe you'll find one to be more clear:

``` ruby
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new                                                
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily.day(:monday, :tuesday, :wednesday, :thursday, :friday).day_of_month(17)
                                                                                
puts schedule.first(10).inspect                                                 
                                                                                
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new                                                
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily.day_of_month(17)                             
schedule.exrule IceCube::Rule.daily.day(:saturday, :sunday)                     
                                                                                
puts schedule.first(10).inspect 
```

Either way, you'll get:

ActiveSupport is optional in this gem.

@seuros It was optional, but it also is broken in Ruby 2.5 as a result.  I think I can fix this particular issue without recourse to ActiveSupport, but I don't know if that is true in the broader sense.
The failure in the spec is from `ruby-head`.  I'm not familiar enough with what is changing in Ruby 2.6 to know what the cause is.

Investigating leads me to believe this is related to issue #435 regarding `psych` returning times without zones in the YAML deserialization.  The gem is trying to match the date given to the time zone that doesn't exist, and that's the source of the error.

Further investigation leads to the result that `build_in_zone` in TimeUtil assumes that if the reference does not have a time zone, all the arguments are there for building a time using `Time.new(*args << reference.utc_offset)`.  The date does not have the last three arguments (hours, minutes, and seconds) and so this building of the time fails.

I'm going to work on a PR to fix this problem with `build_in_zone`, at least.

When upgrading an older app from a previous version of Ruby to Ruby 2.5.1, our application was having an `out of range` error. This was solved by changing the following:

`@time.schedule.next_occurrence((Time.now).to_date)`

to

`@time.schedule.next_occurrence((Time.now).to_time)`
Also relevant: https://github.com/rails/rails/commit/e9bd957064a040fdd80e2b6d3fb0b793ccb9cce1

This is a **_major_** issue for me, as it is resulting in `next_occurrence([Date])` producing the same date as is fed into it in many cases, due to the loss of the time zone information. If someone has a solution, it would help a lot for it to happen sooner rather than later.

For instance, on Ruby 2.4, this works:

```ruby
date = Date.current
loop do
  date = schedule.next_occurrence(date).to_date
  break if date > 2.months.from_now
  puts date
end
```

In Ruby 2.5, that produces an argument error `out of range`.  Replacing the next_occurrence call with `schedule.next_occurrence(date.to_time)` produces an infinite loop if the current time zone is not the one the schedule `start_time` originally had.  I've had to tack on an `end_of_day` as a workaround, but I already see cases where that might fail too - mostly hoping I don't run into them.

you may check this out for more examples
[https://gist.github.com/nathancolgate/4998196](https://gist.github.com/nathancolgate/4998196)

Updated to version `0.16.2`, exactly the issue described is fixed, but `start_time` inside the rule is nevertheless overwritten.

Not sure if this is a problem, but you should decide whether you investigate it or not

Thanks for reporting. I'm glad it's working correctly in the latest version and I'm aware this could still be an issue when using the same schedule object between different threads.

The instance variables under the rules are there to set the starting point for the current method call, and they are reset when querying again. Yes, it would be better to refactor this so there is no state left behind in the rule instances between different requests; but it would need lots of internal changes.

I believe this is because single occurrence rules are actually `exception_times`, not `exception_rules`.
Closing, see discussion on linked issue.

"Exception Rules" and "Exception Times" are different.

Both are handled internally as types of "Rules", but different types go into each category:

- `add_recurrence_rule`: add all except single times (Daily, etc.) to `@all_recurrence_rules`
- `add_recurrence_time`: add single times only to `@all_recurrence_rules`
- `add_exception_rule`: add all except single times (Daily, etc.) to `@all_exception_rules`
- `add_exception_time`: add single times only to `@all_exception_rules`

Reading `exception_rules` and `exception_times` should only give the different types back, so I don't think this is a bug: there are different methods for accessing these.

Exception Rules are [deprecated][2] in the newer iCalendar RFC 5545, (see the older iCalendar  [RFC 2445][1] for reference). For now we continue to support them.

We can discuss what you're looking for, if there's an underlying reason for this issue, but let's close the PR #428 for now.

[1]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2445#section-4.8.5.2
[2]: https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#appendix-A.3

I'm using ice-cube for scheduling recurrent event in a project I'm
working on.

The original issue that got me into this was like this:
1. Create a schedule with recurrent rule (say daily)
2. Add a exception time
3. Update =schedule.start_time=
4. *The exception rule is no longer effective now* (Because it's a
SingleOccurrenceRule for a specific time and =schedule.start_time= was
changed)

The script to reproduce this:
```ruby
    schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.parse('12:00'))
    schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.daily)

    schedule.next_occurrence
    # => 2017-10-17 12:00:00 +0800

    schedule.add_exception_time(schedule.next_occurrence)
    # => 2017-10-17 12:00:00 +0800
    schedule.next_occurrence
    # => 2017-10-18 12:00:00 +0800

    schedule.start_time = Time.parse('13:00')
    # => 2017-10-17 13:00:00 +0800
    schedule.next_occurrence
    # => 2017-10-17 13:00:00 +0800
    # But I want the exception_rule to be synced with schedule.start_time
    # So the next_occurrence will be 2017-10-18 13:00:00 +0800
```

The solution I came up with was to get all exception time and update
their times one by one, which is not very efficient but we can take it
for now.

exception rules but it didn't work (since I was using
@add_exception_time@ to add rule)

I think the problem here is about naming, I thought:
1. @exception_rules@ was about getting all exception rules instead of
all except single times
2. @exception_times@ was using @exception_rules@ to get all rules and
convert them into times

And I double checked SingleOccurrenceRule, it inherits Rule but it
doesn't implement to_ical method, which is a bit odd to me.

Maybe we can come up with better names to distinguish these methods and
classes better? (Or is there any background I'm missing here?)

@uzaif313 
If what you need is to update a *specific* Monday, instead of every Monday, then I think it can be achieved by:
1. Use `add_exception_time` to exclude that specific Monday for this event
2. Create a non-recurrent event for this Monday named "Macaroni & Cheese"

So, in general, I don't think this is a question about this library. Someone correct me if I'm wrong, but this library only deals with recurrence rules. Giving events a single name is outside the scope of this library, let alone giving them multiple names. You'll need to write custom logic to handle this in your app. I imagine the "best" implementation will be heavily dependent on the structure of the rest of your app.

Adding "names" and other data about schedules and events is outside the scope of this library.

Only your own application can know how to best handle this, so it's up to you to _attach_ a schedule to your own objects.

Agree with this - `end_time` always felt a bit weird to me.  What do you think the interface should be here for `duration` being able to take nominal times?

Well, let's look at the options:

### "Numeric" values

```
schedule.duration = 3600    # SECONDS, unchanged
schedule.duration = 1.month # MONTH if recognizable via ActiveSupport
```

### Hash value
(Seems most obvious)
```
schedule.duration = {days: 1, hours: 2}
```



### Array
(Not sure if useful)
```
schedule.duration = [0, 0, 1, 2, 0, 0]  # Same as Time constructor (Y, M, D, H, M, S)
```



### String value
(Maybe only useful for `from_ical` parsing?)

```
schedule.duration = "P15DT5H0M20S" # 15 DAY, 5 HOUR, 20 SEC
```

For reference: iCalendar RFC [DURATION][1]


[1]: https://icalendar.org/iCalendar-RFC-5545/3-3-6-duration.html

Hey @avit,

I'm not 100% sure about the `next_occurrence` implementation, but I understood that `spans: true` can be set if a "overlapping" occurrence is fine as well (i.e start_time is before - and end_time is after reference date) or if the next occurrence must start after given reference date (i.e. both start_time and end_time have to be after the reference date).

If that understanding is correct, `spans: true` would be required to return the expected occurrence from the example above (`2017-10-28 16:00:00 +0200 - 2017-10-29 09:00:00 +0100`). `spans: false` should return the current result of the example above (`2017-10-29 16:00:00 +0100 - 2017-10-30 09:00:00 +0100`).

Ok, I looked into this further and confirmed it's not a bug.

Your example schedule has a duration of 17 hours: that means each occurrence must have the same length.

Because the end of DST adds one hour, that occurrence actually ends at 08:00, not at 09:00 like on other days, so the selection of the "next occurrence" is correct.

I considered whether the occurrence should have a different length in this situation, but based on [the spec][1], it should not. Internally, we specify the duration in seconds so it should always be an exact period. However, the spec _does_ allow for setting duration in different amounts, e.g. "1D" should mean a day, regardless of whether it is 24 or 25 hours... IceCube currently doesn't support this, but it could be added without changing the current meaning of duration.

[1]: https://icalendar.org/iCalendar-RFC-5545/3-3-6-duration.html

This looks correct to me.

> its not display hourly based count for other days

You have set `hourly(3)` = every 3 hours, and `count(4)` = 4 times only. The 4 hourly occurrences are based on the start time, and then they stop: 

```
[2017-08-17 00:00:00 +0530,
 2017-08-17 03:00:00 +0530,
 2017-08-17 06:00:00 +0530,
 2017-08-17 09:00:00 +0530,
```

After this, the hourly rule is done because of the count limit, so it does the `daily.day(1,3,5)` occurrences only.

You can do it with 3 daily rules:

```
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.hour_of_day(3)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.hour_of_day(6)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily.hour_of_day(9)
```

Or 1 hourly rule:

```
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.hourly.hour_of_day(3, 6, 9)
```

The first way is more efficient, but both of these will work.

Thanks, confirmed. Looking at it.

It looks like this is happening because you are setting a Date for the until, and it's expecting a Time.

Setting it with Date is ambiguous, and I believe incorrect that we allow it, so we should prevent bad input from failing silently like this. 

There are a few places where we allow Date input because we can use the schedule's context to convert it to the proper time zone. In the case of `Schedule.new(Time.zone.today)` and then `Rule.new(Date.today)`, these are independent inputs and the new rule doesn't know the schedule's time context for us to convert it. (We would have to change the API for building rules to support that.)

I'm going to add some input checking for the next version, but you can work around this in the meantime.
My mistake, it should be possible to set the `until` using a Date after all: we do get the correct context later when evaluating the schedule, so it is just a problem with serialization.
That I did not see! Thanks for this fix, just wanted to let you know that it fixes the problem! 👍

Actually, reading this again it looks like that's what you're doing. I'll have a closer look.

This isn't an IceCube issue; you need Ruby or Rails to do some of that work for you. `Schedule.all` returns a collection of schedules, so you'll need to run a `map` or similar function to merge the occurrences from each instance together.

You could add a class method on your Schedule model:

```
class Schedule < AR::B
  def self.occurrences(*args)
    all.flat_map { |s| s.occurrences(*args) }.sort!.uniq!
  end
end
```

Hi Ryan,

This was removed purposefully because it was all too easy to serialize a schedule that excludes itself, and this would cause apps to go into an infinite loop at some unexpected time in the future when the schedule gets reloaded.

Can you work around this by defining your schedules differently?

It might be possible for us to keep it in `to_hash` and only remove it when going `to_json` and `to_yaml` with a warning. That's open to discussion, so you could still shoot yourself in the foot with `to_hash.to_yaml`...

```
module IceCube

What should it return instead? It's hard to guess what the default value should be: I don't think it's safe to assume a single occurrence for Time.now.

I think nil is the right thing to load, unless we define a special "zero occurrence" schedule. Or am I missing something?

>  It's hard to guess what the default value should be:  I don't think it's safe to assume a single occurrence for Time.now.

```rb
serialize :some_column, IceCube::Schedule
```

Should return an instance of `IceCube::Schedule`.

> I think nil is the right thing to load...

From the [docs for `serialize`](http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActiveRecord/AttributeMethods/Serialization/ClassMethods.html#method-i-serialize):

> If class_name is specified, the serialized object must be of that class on assignment and retrieval.

When you return `nil` you break the contract. 

> unless we define a special "zero occurrence" schedule. Or am I missing something?

`IceCube::Schedule.new` seems fine. If I recall it is a "zero occurrence schedule".

Every schedule stems from a `start_time` and occurs once for this time (by default it's `Time.now`, which would change on every new instance), before you add any recurrence rules. I get what you mean about the type contract but I don't think this would follow the expectation very well.

If the database is storing NULL (an _absence_ of a specified value, not a _default_ or _new_ value) I don't see why we would _want_ to assume anything from it: in this case the record object should not have any schedule until one is explicitly assigned.

Is this causing errors with ActiveRecord? We may have to return something different for handling the null object specially then.

As a side note, I see the docs also mention:

> Empty objects as `{}`, in the case of `Hash`, or `[]`, in the case of `Array`, will always be persisted as null.

So what this implies is that Rails expects nullable columns in the database, but requires their values to somehow still be specified in ActiveRecord!? This mixes up null and empty values as the same thing when they're really not... it's completely different from the type contract of any other kind of column. 😞

@dcosson @seejohnrun Put some more thinking / console testing into this and I may have a solution. We can modify the time zone parser to use `Time.use_zone` instead:

``` ruby
def self._parse_in_tzid(value, tzid)
  time_zone = tzid ? tzid.split('=')[1] : Time.zone
  Time.use_zone time_zone do
    Time.zone.parse(value)
  end
end
```

This will switch `Time` to use the time zone of whatever was specified in the TZID of the iCalendar event, falling back to whatever the system / server is configured to be by default. I believe this produces identical results to using your previous:

``` ruby
ActiveSupport::TimeZone.new(time_zone).parse(value)
```

EDIT: Nevermind, I had ActiveSupport loaded somehow in my Ruby console. `use_zone` is an extension to Time added by ActiveSupport still...

@seejohnrun not quite sure I understand the first suggestion. Unless I'm forgetting something, you don't interact with the parser directly, you call e.g. `IceCube::Schedule.from_ical(ical_string)` to parse the ical string. It seems inconvenient to have a hidden dependency (which is not a gem-level dependency) on ActiveRecord for anyone using the `from_*` methods, because it seems like the majority of people using this library will be serializing & deserializing at some point and so will need to have ActiveRecord.

I'm strongly in favour of making dependencies on libraries like ActiveSupport optional, preferably ignoring them altogether. And let's not forget that people who serialize data don't automatically choose ActiveRecord – there are good reasons to choose different ways of storing data, or different libraries for interacting with a relational DB.

@dcosson What I think @seejohnrun meant when he said "How about when they want the parser having them require in that separately" was that people who need the functionality that depends on ActiveSupport could require that gem themselves (e.g. add it to their bundle) in order to disable the exception you proposed, and enable the functionality.

Exception rules have been deprecated for a long time. This is based on the iCalendar RFC spec.

The "rules" you have above look like individual dates: you can still do `add_exception_time` for those.
To avoid breaking compatibility, we may treat the duration inside the Schedule as the default duration. Then, if a rule specifies a duration, that duration overrides the Schedule's one.

I'm open to it if we can roundtrip iCal export...

Not sure why we didn't get to review and merge this sooner, but thank you! I rebased and merged this now.

Two things are at the core of this issue:
- Rails ActiveSupport defines `1.month == 30.days`, except when you add it to a time
- IceCube schedules can have only one duration for all occurrences

If you try `time + 1.month`, you will see how ActiveSupport does arithmetic: it does some special handling to add the correct number of days based on the current month (30, 31, 28, or 29 days).

However, this is not reliable for exporting to iCal or serializing to hash / YAML format, so we use the strict single duration for the whole schedule.

If your occurrences always run for 1 month, you can work around this by not relying on the duration at all, and just compare the year and month yourself to see if it's "occurring" in the time window.

I'm sorry I can't see a good way to fix this right now, but different durations for occurrences do come up frequently, so we might look into that in the future. It looks like multiple values should be supported as shown in [the spec](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.3.6), but it also says it doesn't support "M" for month durations either...

I fixed this by making `IceCube.compatibility` match he released version number. "start_date" was still there to output for the older serialized format, but that's unsupported now.

Thanks for the contribution though!

When you change the start time, the rules are not changed. It still uses the 9th day of the month if you lock that in with `day_of_month`. Try like this:

```
pst_tz = ActiveSupport::TimeZone['America/Vancouver']
ist_tz = ActiveSupport::TimeZone['Asia/Kolkata']
pst_time = pst_tz.parse("201601092000000") # -08:00
ist_time = pst_time.in_time_zone(ist_tz)

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(pst_time) do |s|
  s.rrule IceCube::Rule.monthly.count(10)
end
schedule.next_occurrences(2)
#=> [Tue, 09 Feb 2016 20:00:00 PST -08:00, Wed, 09 Mar 2016 20:00:00 PST -08:00]

schedule.start_time = ist_time
schedule.next_occurrences(2)
#=> [Wed, 10 Feb 2016 09:30:00 IST +05:30, Thu, 10 Mar 2016 09:30:00 IST +05:30]
```

```
sunday = Time.new(2016, 1, 31, 0, 0, 0)
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(sunday, duration: 3600 * 3) do |s|
  s.rrule(IceCube::Rule.weekly)
end
schedule.next_occurrences(8).map { |occurrence| occurrence.end_time.hour }

#=> [3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 3, 4, 3]
```

You can set an exception time (`add_exception_time` / `extime`) for your schedule, but there is no way to replace it with an occurrence of a different length. (Duration is global to the whole schedule.)

These occurrences still have the same duration, so they are technically valid. I don't think raising an exception applies.

What we could add is a method that tells you if the occurrence is affected by DST change. Something like this?

```
occurrence.dst_change?  #=> true
occurrence.dst_change  #=> 0 or -3600.0 or 3600.0
```

Depending on your circumstance you could subtract that from the end time. Would that work?

I know the branch says "3_lines", but I needed to support all-day events for RDATE and EXDATE, so this version does that.

It also allows for some "extensions" on parsing iCal lines, including (a) blank lines, and (b) comment lines starting with "#", and (c) if a line looks like a date "yyyymmdd", treat it as an RDATE automatically.

These extensions are all disabled by default, but can be enabled with `IceCube::IcalParser.use_extensions = true`, or setting env var `ICE_CUBE_ICAL_EXTS` to non-empty.

@corroded check the start times you are passing into the schedule:

```
est_string = 'Eastern Time (US & Canada)'

before_dst = Time.new(2015, 10, 27, 5, 15, 0, 0).in_time_zone(est_string)
#=> Tue, 27 Oct 2015 01:15:00 EDT -04:00

after_dst = Time.new(2015, 11, 03, 5, 15, 0, 0).in_time_zone(est_string)
#=> Tue, 03 Nov 2015 00:15:00 EST -05:00
```

Note the hour on these starts out different because of how they were defined. "05:15 +0000" is offset differently from EST depending on the time of year.

@jacaetevha trying the same thing in plain ruby will get you different results. DST only works with your `ENV['TZ']`, where you can use `Time.local`. If you build a time with a manual offset (or different TZ) then it will stay fixed and not change with DST.

I have this use case in my application. My logic is something like this:
- If the user is available
- And if the schedule `occurs_at` at current time
- Run the processing

There is also another rub: I run my scheduler every ten minutes or so to pick up jobs that are due. I have to account for the scheduler not running exactly at 9am -- it might run at 9.01am. Typically, setting a duration helps, or here, since you have a window, the scheduler is likely to run at least once in the window of availability. 

I could have had exceptions per user, but since a task typically is assigned to a group, I decided to add a little logic just to police the per user availability. (I actually have lots of other rules, too, such as expiries , whether that are recurrence rules for a task, etc.)

So, I guess what I'm saying is, you could create a schedule of availability per user, and then a schedule for your tasks, and both have to agree it is time to actually run something.

Without time zone it falls back to Time.parse which uses system time zone, ignoring zone configured in ActiveSupport. IceCube docs mention using ActiveSupport time zone support, so would be great to try Time.zone.parse first, and then fall back to Time.parse.

UPDATE: Actually, IceCube seems to ignore time zone too, so I suppose the problem it's beyond scope of this PR.

What's blocking this from being merged? This is a really bad bug, the `from_ical` method imports things at the wrong time whenever a timezone is used in the ical (which is completely legit by the standard)

Example:

```
[0] pry(main)> now = Time.now.in_time_zone('America/Los_Angeles');
[1] pry(main)> now.utc
=> 2016-05-10 00:02:05 UTC
[2] pry(main)> IceCube::Schedule.from_ical(IceCube::Schedule.new(now).to_ical).start_time
=> 2016-05-09 17:02:05 +0000
```

As you can see, it changes the time anytime you deserialize the value.

(Sorry for super late reply)

For what it's worth, I'm using the [icalendar](https://github.com/icalendar/icalendar) gem to do this in an application where we're using `ice_cube`. Something like:

``` ruby
class Whatever < ActiveRecord::Base
  validate :_schedule_ical_has_valid_syntax, if: :schedule_ical

  def _schedule_ical_has_valid_syntax
    icalendar = _parse_icalendar

    if icalendar.empty? || icalendar.first.events.empty? || !icalendar.first.events.first.valid?
      errors.add :schedule_ical, "is not valid ICAL syntax"
    end
  end

  def _schedule_ical_with_wrapper
    [
      "BEGIN:VCALENDAR",
      "VERSION:2.0",
      "PRODID:validationid",
      "CALSCALE:GREGORIAN",
      "BEGIN:VEVENT",
      schedule_ical,
      "END:VEVENT",
      "END:VCALENDAR"
    ].join("\n")
  end

  def _parse_icalendar
    Icalendar.parse(_schedule_ical_with_wrapper)
  end
end
```

Icalendar seems to be the right tool for the job. I think it makes sense if we start using it for import/export. It has no extra runtime dependencies (same as IceCube) so I'd be :+1:  depending on it for this.

Maybe I'm misunderstanding what this is for... is this related to #282?

Schedules are already serialized with the time zone preserved when you create your schedule using a time zone. It stores the UTC timestamp, plus the original time zone annotation.

This would lose the original time zone context when serializing the schedule:

```
def self.serialize_time(time)
  time.utc
end
```

Are you trying to access TimeUtil directly or what is this for?

Correct, schedules are serialized with the current time zone. Let's say the user creates the event when their time zone is EST and then later changes their time zone to PST. Now when In interpret those events they will continue to reference their EST time instead of PST which is what the user expects. Since the time zone is serialized into the schedule, I would have to go and update every schedule when the user changes their time zone.

This patch always serializes to UTC and when I deserialize I use the user's time zone.

I don't think this makes sense to add to the gem, but I'm glad it's working for your use case.

Another option might be to use the standard behaviour, and then adjust the schedule's time zone when reloading it:

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.from_yaml(record.schedule)
schedule.start_time = schedule.start_time.in_time_zone(user.time_zone)
```

Adding the hash method makes sense, for purposes of object value equality (which just returns an integer for comparison). (PR welcome if I don't get to it!)

I don't see how the "native hash serializer" is related to this though, I'm assuming you mean postgres Hstore? (Just to be sure we're on the same page, `#to_hash` is not the same thing as `#hash`.)

YAML is used because we need to include time zone, not just a fixed offset. Note how "PST" gets lost, at least when converting to JSON:

```
Time.zone = 'America/Vancouver'
#=> "America/Vancouver"
Time.zone.now
#=> Fri, 20 Feb 2015 11:53:07 PST -08:00
Time.zone.now.to_json
#=> "\"2015-02-20T11:53:17.161-08:00\""
```

You would need to keep the correct time zone to handle Daylight Saving Time. I'm not familiar with recent changes in Rails serialization, is your proposed implementation able to handle that?

We're using IceCube to create a schedule for an user and sometimes we want to unschedule a user for a certain amount of time. 

A use case could be the following;

An user has an schedule from 1 October till 31 October. But the user will be on vacation from 15 October till 20 october. 

So we want to "unschedule" the user for this period. What would you suggest to tackle this problem?

A couple of options:

You _could_ set fixed exception times within the schedule,

```
schedule.occurrences_between(vac_start, vac_end).each do |vac_time|
  schedule.add_exception_time(vac_time)
end
```

The downside is that it's specific to exactly that schedule, so it has to match the time for each occurrence exactly. If you move the schedule by an hour then those exception times won't line up anymore. Depending how you work with these schedules, this approach might work for you. 

However, it might be better to store & handle those time ranges separately from the schedule itself, which would be more flexible since I assume you'll want to "manage" vacations anyway...

I've added a wiki page describing that since it could be useful to others.

Thanks @avit. I see you can read the rule in two different ways and I couldn't say my interpretation is any more valid.

In our application we have some rules that enforce when time periods can start, sort of like _setup time_. If `today` was **January the 1st**, and there is **2 days** of _setup time_, the earliest date we can allow would be the **3rd**. We wanted to be able to say something like `every two months, on the 1st of the month, from the 3rd of January`. As is, `IceCube` wouldn't do what we'd expect in giving us the **1st of Feb**, instead it would be the **1st of March**, skipping our intended month.

To get around this, we currently calculate `IceCube`'s `start_time` by setting `interval` to `1` and getting the `next_occurrence` in the schedule. Is there an alternative approach you could suggest?

I can understand if you want to keep the current behaviour, but I thought you may find it useful to hear our use case :)

We try to follow the [iCalendar RFC](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545) specification. I can't see if this ambiguity between DTSTART, BYMONTHDAY, and INTERVAL is resolved there, but there is some logical order for how these rules are applied.

I also like to test some other tool like Apple's Calendar app to validate any assumptions. I just tried adding an event starting Nov 3, with a "custom" schedule of every 2 months, occurring on the 1st of the month. The first occurrence disappeared from Nov 3 (since it's not valid as "1st of the month"), and reappeared on January 1st. This matches what IceCube does.

It sounds like you're doing it right by resetting the start time to the first valid occurrence before increasing the interval, if that's what you expect in your case.

Please close this if your question is answered, I don't think there's a bug to be fixed.

I also read through the RFC but it doesn't seem to cover this scenario explicitly. Interestingly, I attempted the same schedule in iCal (Yosemite) and instead of moving the first occurrence to January 1st, it moved to 1st December. I'm pretty sure I followed the same steps as you did.

Either way, I appreciate your explanation and thank you for being a part of a fantastic open source project!

@bloomdido I am not sure if we are talking of the same thing. My initial implementation tested timezones as well.  I simplified the code before posting.

```
def eql?(other)
  other.is_a?(IceCube::Schedule) &&

@gsusmonzon Actually, I just checked and I don't think you have a problem because you used `serialize :schedule, IceCube::Schedule` instead of `serialize :schedule` like I did. This seems to do the trick, probably because it uses the `IceCube::Schedule dump/load` methods instead of the Ruby YAML coder (which uses `init_with` and `encode_with`). I wish I had done this originally and I wouldn't have been struggling for the last three weeks to figure out why my schedules kept changing after they were saved...

Here the issue in the Rails project:

https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/9183

I wound up monkey patching ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone to properly serialize/deserialize from YAML in my code. However, this solution is not going to work for IceCube. I'll look into coming up with a solution next week. I think its probably going to involve updating the TimeUtil serialize_time/deserialize_time methods to handle TimeWithZone (and possibly Time, since it doesn't save/restore time zones either).

Just an update on this issue - serializing DateTime, Time, or TimeWithZone objects will all cause problems because none of them _currently_ save the time zone. I'm planning to write some test cases to demonstrate the problem, then go about creating a PR to fix it. I think the only real solution is to save the time zone along with any time object when serializing. Since the JSON time format doesn't support time zones either (only offsets), there is a loss of data there, too. But I don't think IceCube has a from_json method right now, so it's not as big of an issue.

As for why the time zone offset isn't enough, I refer you to @avit's comment here: https://github.com/rails/rails/issues/9183

BTW, here's quick & dirty test that highlights this issue:

```
Time.zone = 'Pacific Time (US & Canada)'
start_time = Time.zone.parse('2014-10-21 21:00:00')
end_time = Time.zone.parse('2014-10-22 01:00:00')
until_time = Time.zone.parse('2014-11-04')
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, end_time: end_time)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(:tuesday).until(until_time.end_of_day)
schedule_yaml = YAML.load(YAML.dump(schedule))

schedule.all_occurrences
=> [Tue, 21 Oct 2014 21:00:00 PDT -07:00, Tue, 28 Oct 2014 21:00:00 PDT -07:00, Tue, 04 Nov 2014 21:00:00 PST -08:00]

schedule_yaml.all_occurrences
=> [2014-10-28 04:00:00 UTC, 2014-11-04 04:00:00 UTC]
```

As you can see, the last occurrence crosses daylight savings time (so the offset changes from -07:00 to -08:00), and so just saving the offset alone is not going to work. This is why the time zone itself must be serialized.

FYI, this is the monkey patch I am currently using to workaround this issue:

```
# patch TimeWithZone to serialize properly to/from YAML
class ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone
  def init_with(coder)
    initialize(coder[:utc].utc, ::Time.find_zone(coder[:zone]), coder[:time].utc)
  end

  def encode_with(coder)
    coder.tag = '!ruby/object:ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone'
    coder.map = {utc: utc, zone: time_zone.name, time: time}
  end
end
```

Thanks for the input on this @bloomdido. Actually I was unaware of this problem, probably since I covered it with an additional gem to support serializing with ActiveRecord and forgot all about it in our app:

https://github.com/avit/schedule_attributes/blob/master/lib/schedule_attributes/serializer.rb

Currently IceCube's own `to_yaml` is a bit different than your example above. We don't output the ruby/object annotation because the `from_yaml` method handles the deserialization, but I don't think it would hurt to add it either.

So it sounds like this will be fixed upstream in 4.2... Do you think this monkey patch should be handled by IceCube when ActiveSupport < 4.2 is loaded?

Oh, it looks like you already addressed that problem somewhat with this:

```
# Check the deserialized time offset string against actual local time
# offset to try and preserve the original offset for plain Ruby Time. If
# the offset is the same as local we can assume the same original zone and
# keep it.  If it was serialized with a different offset than local TZ it
# will lose the zone and not support DST.
def self.restore_deserialized_offset(time, orig_offset_str)
  return time if time.respond_to?(:time_zone) ||
                 time.getlocal(orig_offset_str).utc_offset == time.utc_offset
  warn "IceCube: parsed Time from nonlocal TZ. Use ActiveSupport to fix DST at: #{ caller[0] }"
  time.localtime(orig_offset_str)
end
```

Yes, IceCube handles the conversion correctly as long as you use those to/from methods. Adding the `ruby/object` annotation to our YAML output might break things if TimeWithZone doesn't support the zone correctly yet.

As for the core ruby classes, I think everything is working well as it stands. They work exactly as the core ruby classes work, so it's predictable based on how you initialize your schedule: you just have to be aware that they're not time-zone aware. (Time does support "local" based on `ENV['TZ']` or "utc", and these work fine if you only need to support a single time zone.)

The warning in the above method should cover it. I think we can close this issue?

Yeah, I just realized that if I use `serialize :column, IceCube::Schedule` instead of just `serialize :column`, it will use the `IceCube::Schedule dump/load` methods and work just fine. Wish I'd know that weeks ago - could have saved me a lot of headaches. I guess I can take solace in the fact that I probably helped accelerate the fix in `ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone` when serializing to/from YAML. :)

I18n default time format is memoized here: https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube.rb#L71, so when you run the whole suite it takes the value the first time (english format) and keeps on with that even if you change the `I18n.locale`.

That start time looks like a fixed offset, not a time zone, so it doesn't know of DST. What is your system time zone?

If you're handling this without Rails or ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone then you'll have to set your TZ environment for ruby to match the time zone you are working with:

```
ENV['TZ'] = 'America/New_York'
```

It might be easier to load `active_support/time` and let it handle everything for you.

If I am reading correctly, when you create your schedule via `IceCube::Schedule.new`, you are implicitly setting a `start_date` by not passing any arguments, which I think ends up acting as a min date for occurrences.  You can set a start date by calling `IceCube::Schedule.new(start_date)`.  If you don't want this, maybe you could try passing the epoch time (ie. 0 in unix time)?
That's correct. The schedule's start time defaults to the current time. Otherwise you need to say when to start from.
The intention of that line of code is to jump ahead to the start time if you select a time before the schedule start time, to optimize searching.

FYI, in my previous comment I suggested that you might pass a the unix epoch as a date to hack around your problem, but I just ran into the issue that certain methods on `Schedule` (eg. `Schedule.previous_occurrence`) will take prohibitively long if you do that, probably because it's iterating through all the earlier occurrences.

Got it.
As one new library user's opinion, it still feels more intuitive if `occurrences_between` works with past start time though..

I'm not sure what's happening outside the context of what you showed there, but one thing to remember is that IceCube rules are immutable. That means when you chain a method to add extra validations on the rule, it always returns a new rule. It doesn't modify the original.

I expect this should work:

```
schedule.recurrence_rules[0] = schedule.recurrence_rules[0].until(cancel_date)
# or
schedule.recurrence_rules.map! { |r| r.until(cancel_date) }
```

> `{time_with_zone: Time.now}.to_json`

This is not a TimeWithZone, it's a plain Time. You only know the offset (-07:00), but not the zone.

If I gave you the offset +01:00, there's no way to tell if it's Central Europe or Western Africa. The time would be wrong for half the year. (One follows Daylight Savings Time and the other doesn't.)

Also, the list of time zone abbreviations is inconsistent, so just adding "PST" as a suffix has its own share of problems. See the [wikipedia page](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_time_zone_abbreviations) for the number of different zones that are all named "CST" for example.

Hope that makes sense? I'm happy to answer any questions about it but I don't think we should change it.

We should not bump the compatibility until the next version, but we should see if we can silence the problem in the serialization loop, while still warning of any explicit uses of `start_date`.

I fixed up the spec suite to remove references to the old behaviours.

The actual IceCube lib will still warn you of deprecated things with `IceCube.compatibility = 11` If you bump it to 12, it will not output the older `start_date` to the serialized formats, so that will silence it for you. This is in place for anyone who is depending on the `start_date` key outside of IceCube, to be aware that this is now changed to `start_time`.

Set compatibility = 12 if you don't depend on the old behaviour. This will be updated in the next release.

Not sure if already done, but it's probably worth adding a note to the readme about this, maybe recommending that new projects set this in an initializer. 
- alex

The Validation classes are responsible for telling whether a given time is a valid "hit" for the schedule, or how far to jump ahead for the next occurrence opportunity. Since "Validation" is kind of an overloaded term in this gem, I'd prefer not to add a different "Validation" class for checking input. (It's already confusing.)

The Validation classes are the deep internal engine of the library and I don't think we need to be checking things in there. It's the Rule classes that expose the interface, so that's where we should be catching bad inputs up-front.

@wallace thanks for posting the sample rails app: that helps to put this issue in context. In any case this error should not be handled in HashParser. (HashParser should never expect nil as a possible input.)

Two things to consider. Firstly, dumping:

```
IceCube::Schedule.dump(nil)
IceCube::Schedule.dump("")
```

We should change this to not blindly convert `to_yaml` in these scenarios. This allowed your sample model to save with some empty YAML in the first place, which causes problems when reloading. Properly, only `Schedule` instances should be dumpable, not strings, but we should handle `nil` and `""` as special cases. 

Secondly, loading:

```
IceCube::Schedule.load("---\n...\n")
```

I'm debating whether this should just return `nil` or raise an error, although a more helpful one than it currently does. I would actually prefer to see the error, since we should not be accepting arbitrary YAML that doesn't have a `:start_time` at least.

Loading `""` and `nil` already returns nil. it's only the case of actual empty YAML that causes an error.

Fundamentally I think the problem you had was with the dumping, not the loading. Does this make sense?

Hi @avit , thanks for the quick response. The feature we are working on is a sort of 'retroactive' one. We use ice_cube to create a recurring email digest - but we were having trouble with the very first occurrence. Say you want an email digest every 5:00 am daily - we get all emails from the last run up to the next. There are 2 cases here:

if you set the rule AFTER the time, (say rule is 5:00AM daily and you set it at 7:00AM), you will get all messages from 5:00am this morning up to 5:00am tomorrow. If you set the rule BEFORE (rule is 5:00AM but you set it at 4:00AM), we were hoping to send all messages from 5:00AM yesterday to 5:00AM today. This is a simple case, but imagine if the rule was every 7,9th and 13th of the month etc.

Did that make sense?

I see. If you have a rule like "every 7,9th and 13th of the month" and you need to get an old time, you'll need to rewind your start time to the oldest item. It only works by counting forwards from the start time.

We want to keep the compatibility version as a static number: it will often stay behind the current version by default as it is right now (current version = 12, compatibility = 11), so users have a chance to update any deprecated usage.

You should manually set this to 12 in your own configuration if your app is new or you've fixed the deprecation warnings.
In my case the ice_cube gem triggers deprecation warnings. We use `Schedule#to_hash`, which sets `data[:start_date]`, which is deprecated.

We still output `start_date` in the default hash as a stop-gap for anyone who has been depending on this key in their app, giving everyone a warning to change it to `start_time` without breaking. If your app doesn't read the exported hashes outside of IceCube, or you're just building a new app, you should go ahead and confirm that in your configuration manually:

``` ruby
IceCube.compatibility = 12
```

See: [UPGRADING](https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/UPGRADING.md)

In the next release the default will be bumped from 11 to 12, but we want to keep manual control of the default.

@avit In my reading of Myron's comments the 'x.should ==' pattern is the one that he's trying to eliminate.  So I don't really see the point of doing the conversion halfway.  What do you get from that?

The 'x.should ==' pattern:
1. Requires all objects to be decorated such that they respond to 'should'
2. Requires the override of expected behavior for '==', which is a fundamental method

At heart, these two issues are what drove the RSpec 3.x syntax change.

Given there's question about doing the overall transition, I'd recommend pulling out the gemspec fix and RSpec version upgrade into a separate PR and leaving the transpec changes open for longer discussion.

Yeah, the `BasicObject#should` is the part that's in question. What I meant was that this might be the better goal:

``` ruby
# ...
describe "next_occurrence" do
  subject { schedule.next_occurrence }

  it { should be_a Time }
  its(:hour) { should == start_time.hour }

  context "on a full moon" do
    # setup using before / let
    it { should == x }
  end
end
```

This is the ExampleGroup version of should (https://github.com/yujinakayama/transpec#two-types-of-should) which is not going away. I'm not 100% either way, but between the "new" RSpec syntax vs. plain Minitest, I'm starting to lean away from RSpec. I don't expect this test suite will change any time soon, and we do have the rspec development gem locked for "< 3.0" anyway.

Hey guys - so I've been doing some research on this.  The issue stems from `full_required?` being `true` on rules that have intervals `>1` (as per https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/pull/92).  If you take this out, you will get the performance you'd expect back.

Now as to why that's an issue in general - when the interval is `>1` we walk from `start_time` instead of `opening_time`, thus going over a large time range just to determine if `opening_time` is in the proper interval from `start_time`.

Sidetiq will keep around the current `start_time`, which is set as a hard:

``` ruby
# from https://github.com/tobiassvn/sidetiq/blob/master/lib/sidetiq/schedule.rb
START_TIME = Sidetiq.config.utc ? Time.utc(2010, 1, 1) : Time.local(2010, 1, 1)
```

So I'm not sure which side of the usage is the problem - that we should be doing something to provide a `next_occurrence` version which can force `opening_time` instead of `start_time`, or that sidetiq should be setting `start_time` as the occurrence time of the last tick instead of January 1st, 2010.

Why can't we just cache the last time in memory, then the first call to get
the next time will be slow, but thereafter it can be fast?

Pardon.
`day_of_month(-1)`

-1 works if I have param[:day] =31. I have added that condition. But 30 is also last day of month. And for that senario it skips febuaray.  Instead of that I want it to consider 28th/29th as last day (I.e. 30)

you need some domain knowledge there then to consider what "last day" currently means ie:

``` ruby
curr_date = Date.today
ref_date = Date.new(curr_date.year, curr_date.month, params[:day])
day_to_use = ref_date == Date.new(curr_date.year, curr_date.month, -1) ? -1 : params[:day]
```

If you explicitly set the `day_of_month` on your schedule then it will lock to that day and only occur on months that have it. (There is no day_of_month = 30 in February.)

On the other hand, if you just start your schedule on January 30, and just say `monthly` _without_ locking the `day_of_month` then it will include February 28. That's probably what you're looking for.

That's just how it works, everything is based on the start time. I don't think there's a bug here.

So to be more specific, you can get back an `IceCube::Schedule` object with just `serialize :schedule` but it doesn't seem like it goes through the `IceCube::Schedule#dump`/`#load` methods but ruby's built in `Object.to_yaml` methods. The difference being:

### serialize :schedule, IceCube::Schedule

``` yaml
---
:start_date: 2013-11-23 13:45:38.000000000 -05:00
:rrules: []
:exrules: []
:rtimes: []
:extimes: []
```

### serialize :schedule

``` yaml
--- !ruby/object:IceCube::Schedule
start_time: 2013-11-23 13:52:17.000000000 -05:00
all_recurrence_rules: []
all_exception_rules: []

```

Correct, you need to name `IceCube::Schedule` as the serializer class. 

Including the IceCube namespace is optional and doesn't add anything to the ActiveRecord class, except more convenient access to Schedule/Rule classes without needing the `IceCube::` namespace prefix. You might not need it.

Welcome!

> can rescheduling an occurrence to the following day be handled gracefully with a combination of #add_exception_time and adding a single extra occurrence?

Yes, I don't see why not, that's what exceptions are meant for. You can't change the interval "tick" when a scheduled event occurs, but you can mask it with an exception time and add another time in its place.

> are there prefabricated Schedules for like... major US holidays or something similar?

No, we don't have anything like that off the shelf. There is a ticket for supporting `#from_ical` that we expect to merge soon: this could allow you to import from other sources. However, there's no "merge" for schedules if you need to intersect them. At its simplest, this could be just an array of times that you manage yourself, something like this:

``` ruby
holidays.each do |t|
  case t.wday
  when 6 # Saturday, observed on Friday
    schedule.add_exception_time(t)
    schedule.add_recurrence_time(t - 1.day)
  when 7 # Sunday, observed on Monday
    schedule.add_exception_time(t)
    schedule.add_recurrence_time(t + 1.day)
  else
    schedule.add_recurrence_time(t)
  end
end
```

> And a long shot... any frontend (javascript/html) libraries that play nice with this gem, using a similar chaining format for specifying recurrence?

See the wiki! There's a list of related projects and an example model for serializing schedules.  :smile:

s = IceCube::Schedule.from_hash(hash) { |s| s.start_time = Time.now }

If your `schedule.start_time` is "local" (from system TZ e.g. "Europe/London") or in another time zone that follows DST (via ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone), then it will apply the correct time adjustments to the schedule. (10:00 +1:00 → 10:00 +0:00)

If you want to _ignore_ DST, you can use a UTC start time, or a non-zone time with a manual offset:

```
london = ActiveSupport::TimeZone['Europe/London']
london.parse('2013-10-13 10:00')       # adjusts according to selected TimeZone
Time.local(2013, 10, 13, 10)           # adjusts according to system ENV['TZ']
Time.new(2013, 10, 13, 10, 0, 0, 3600) # Uses specified offset year-round
Time.utc(2013, 10, 13, 10, 0, 0)       # UTC, no offset or DST adjustment
```
