Hey Forrest, I changed the title from "infinite loop" since that's not an accurate description: this issue is actually a pretty unique and somewhat interesting edge case. Allow me to expand on what's actually happening:

When DST is ending, the clock time "01:00:00" to "01:59:59" happens twice: once in summer/daylight time, and again when the clock rolls back to standard time. I distinguish these two instances of "1 AM" as the last hour of daylight time, and the first hour of standard time:

| Term | Description |
| --- | --- |
| DT | Daylight Time (Summer), e.g. -0600 MDT |
| ST | Standard Time (Winter), e.g. -0700 MST |
| DT Last Hour | First Sunday in November, Between 01:00 DT and 1:59:59 DT |
| ST First Hour | First Sunday in November, Between 01:00 ST and 1:59:59 ST |

You'll find it's actually fairly unnatural to create a local Time within the DT Last Hour:

```
dt_time = Time.local(2013, 11, 3, 0, 59, 59)
#=> 2013-11-03 00:59:59 -0600

st_time = Time.local(2013, 11, 3, 1, 00, 00)
#=> 2013-11-03 01:00:00 -0700
```

These two look like they should be one second apart, in fact they are 1 hour + 1 second apart; the whole DT Last Hour is skipped. You can fool it with `dt_time + 1` to "slide" into the DT Last Hour. And, of course, you can also get there using _parse_.

IceCube also jumps over the DT Last Hour when traversing daily rules, so that:
- We follow the ruby way when using Time.new (.local) to avoid ambiguity
- We avoid the possibility of duplicates by traversing both DT Last Hour & ST First Hour.

The only time you'll run into your double-occurrence problem is when you explicitly create a daily schedule that starts within DT Last Hour. Normally when traversing over DST, the intervals between daily occurrences are:

| Occurrence | interval to previous time |
| --- | --- |
| 2013-11-01 01:30:00 -0600 | start = 0 |
| 2013-11-02 01:30:00 -0600 | 24 hours |
| 2013-11-03 01:30:00 -0700 | 25 hours |
| 2013-11-04 01:30:00 -0700 | 24 hours |

(In March there's a 23 hours)

When you create a schedule that actually starts in DT Last Hour, that's not a "normal" time we'd ever traverse for a daily rule, so your initial start time before the schedule adjusts itself to get on the right track is an extra:

| Occurrence | interval to previous time |
| --- | --- |
| 2013-11-03 01:30:00 -0600 | start = 0 |
| 2013-11-03 01:30:00 -0700 | 1 hour |
| 2013-11-04 01:30:00 -0700 | 24 hours |

I would recommend not creating things that start in DT Last Hour. Traversing over it works fine, just not as the start time.

I suppose that's not 100% avoidable, so it might be reasonable to skip the "correct" scheduled daily occurrence for Nov 3 so there aren't two occurrences on the same day. It just means the 25-hour interval happens one day later than normal:

| Occurrence | interval to previous time |
| --- | --- |
| 2013-11-03 01:30:00 -0600 | start = 0 |
| 2013-11-04 01:30:00 -0700 | 25 hours |
| 2013-11-05 01:30:00 -0700 | 24 hours |

Does that make sense?

We convert end_time into duration internally, so whatever is the duration of the first occurrence will extend to all occurrences. In this case, because it's created in that limbo hour, the occurrences will have an extra hour duration if you defined it using an end_time.

For future reference, I ended creating multiple events for each occurrence, which seems to work on all clients. Something like:

``` ruby
s.occurences_between(1.month.ago, 1.year.since).each do |occ|
  ical << "BEGIN:VEVENT"
  ical << "UID:#{event_id}-#{occ.strftime(%Y-%m-%d)}@my-domain.com"
  ical << "DTSTART#{IceCube::IcalBuilder.ical_format(occ, true)}"
  ical << "END:VEVENT"
end
```

Each schedule has ONE start time & duration which it uses as the base for its rules, so there's no way to merge schedules for different start times or durations... again, this is how iCalendar works & we have to remain compatible.

You might have to allow your objects to hold multiple schedules & just merge the results.

Also don't forget the duration: `sched.duration = other_schedule.duration`

I don't think dup will create a deep copy of each rule's validations, but otherwise it looks like that should work fine.
A schedule always counts the start time as an occurrence. This was added in 0.10, since that's how iCalendar works too, see #135.

`to_hash` actually looks at the validations, so either method will work fine.

You can also have a look at how the builders are implemented (called from `ValidatedRule#to_hash`, `to_s`, and `to_ical`), maybe you can create your own to extract just the information you need.

How are you passing the time into it? Which regular expression do you mean?

IceCube doesn't accept strings, it should receive a time object directly  (`Time`, `Date`, `ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone`), which you can parse according to whatever format before passing it in.

But it would be nice if it accepts strings, since I could use rails convention to serialize ice_cube attribute into json and the convert it back. The process would become much smoother if it accepts strings.

Strings can introduce ambiguity: [the ISO time format doesn't include a time zone](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ISO_8601#Time_zone_designators), so while this would work for "Z" time, other offsets are unclear about the actual zone, which is needed for the daylight saving time period.

IceCube already natively serializes to/from YAML with the correct zone information if you use `Time.zone` in Rails. I think parsing time shouldn't be a core function of this library, there are already other tools for that, e.g. extended core Time (with `require "time"`):

```
require 'time'
Time.parse('2013-07-03T04:00:00.000Z')
# => 2013-07-03 04:00:00 UTC
```

...which looks correct. I can't guess how you're getting that +08:00 time from IceCube. You would need to show your code.

instead of using `include IceCube`, you should reference it as `IceCube::Schedule`.

Yes, it does look at all the rules and make intelligent jumps forward in time. Each rule has a set of validations which must be met for a time to be included in the schedule. Each validation either returns 0 for a given time if the time matches, or a positive number to jump ahead when this validation would next be valid, e.g. next day, next month, next year, etc. It then jumps to the nearest possible interval from the set of validations and runs again.

See the `validation_accepts_or_updates_time` method which orchestrates it:

https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/validated_rule.rb#L115

Then, each validation has a "validate" method that returns a jump number in seconds (0 = match). This line does a lot of the jumping magic for finding the next fixed interval (plus the special case methods `validate_hour_lock` & `validate_day_lock`):

https://github.com/seejohnrun/ice_cube/blob/master/lib/ice_cube/validations/lock.rb#L14

Yea, it can be a little cryptic to follow at first.

That's a super hard problem to generalize, because you'd need to store so much information to make the full set of query operations work.  Your best bet is to denormalize it and then query on that instead. So when you wanted to do something you hadn't accounted for, you could still iterate and find by the more complicated thing.

So you'd have a table that would store something like

Schedule

- day_of_week

@pencilcheck That's not very efficient, what if you have thousands or millions of scheduled records? You can't efficiently select all of them and check each schedule to see if it matches a given date... that's why you need to denormalize & store what you need to search by so you can join it to your records in a database query.

It's a solution, and it's similar to database searches as well, you still have to go through every record if you don't have any understanding of the records, like indexes.

Normalization is not a good solution, since that would mean extra work on the developer side to simply make a specific query work.

We can simply improve the iteration solution with indexes to speed up the query given that the recurring events don't change much.

This was a bit of an edge case when using `next_occurrence` and the distance from `time - start_time` (29) would equal `days_to_next_month` (29) so the step to the next  time evaluated to zero.

We actually don't need to consider `days_to_next_month` unless there's a chance the next month is shorter (e.g. schedule start is on the 28th or after). In all other cases we can safely advance by the number of days in the current month, which avoids the issue.

The problem here looks like the same as #158. I've addressed them both together.
The start time is counted as an occurrence too, so `:count => 1` will only get you the schedule's start time.

Just confirmed this behaviour in [iCalendar 3.3.10](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.3.10):

> ```
>   The COUNT rule part defines the number of occurrences at which to
>   range-bound the recurrence.  The "DTSTART" property value always
>   counts as the first occurrence.
> ```

It still uses the schedule's start time as the base, every occurrence is based on that. We've just wrapped up the occurrence times in a class so that instead of having just the time of each occurrence you can also get the occurrence's end if it has a duration:

```
s.next_occurrence.start_time # a time, like before
s.next_occurrence.end_time # new functionality

An "occurrence" refers to each start time. So the `_occurrences` and `occurs_` methods will give you the start times that appear in the window. The `occurring_` methods consider the duration as well, so it will tell you if an occurrence is happening even if its start time is before the window.

Hi @vpsheth, this is actually a great question. Masking one schedule ("holidays") against another ("courses") seems like a useful thing. It think it might be worthwhile to have an example implementation of something like this out there, or at least a page with examples in the Wiki (maybe you could contribute something after you work this out?). Although I've never used IceCube for this sort of thing myself, here's how I might do it.

I'm assuming your courses have a daily-repeating schedule, something like this:

``` ruby
cs101 = IceCube::Schedule.new
cs101.start_time = Time.zone.local(2013, 9, 9, 8, 30)
cs101.duration   = 1.hour
cs101.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(1, 3, 5))
     .until(Time.new(2014, 6, 20, 15, 30))
# => [Weekly on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays until June 20, 2014]
```

The above has occurrences like Monday 8:30, Wednesday 8:30, etc... In order to mask these times with your holidays, the holidays should be events with a duration (usually increments of whole days), e.g.

``` ruby
winter_break = IceCube::Schedule.new
winter_break.start_time = Date.new(2013, 12, 23)
winter_break.end_time   = Date.new(2014, 1, 2)
# the whole break is a single occurrence, but you might find repeating rules for these:
winter_break.add_recurrence_time(winter_break.start_time)
# (adding a single occurrence is redundant, should be addressed in #135)
```

You should consider storing each holiday with its own schedule. This will allow for different lengths of events (in number of days) instead of managing individual days & ensuring you have a continuous range. (Then, these can be built into a holidays.ics calendar by wrapping each schedule in a [VEVENT](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.6.1).)

Now, when holidays change, you can update your master "exception days" list. This doesn't even need to be persisted as it's just a dynamic set (or array) of dates generated from the holiday schedules.

``` ruby
def Holiday.flush_exdates!(future = nil)
  future ||= Date.new(2014, 12, 31)
  @exdates = pluck(:schedule).reduce(Set.new) do |holidays, schedule| 
    schedule.occurrences(future).each do |occurrence|
      holidays += (occurrence.to_date ... (occurrence + schedule.duration).to_date).to_a
    end
  end
end
```

Next, for the course schedules you can either persist the updated extimes into them, or mask them dynamically like this:

``` ruby
def Holiday.is_holiday?(time)
  @exdates || flush_exdates!
  @exdates.include? time.to_date
end

class Course < ActiveRecord::Base
  def masked_schedule(future  = nil)
    future ||= Date.new(2014, 12, 31)
    schedule.dup.tap do |s|
      s.extimes = s.occurrences(future).select { |time| Holiday.is_holiday?(time) }
    end
  end
end
```

I'll close this now, but feel free to continue discussion. If the above works for you, it would be nice to write up the actual solution. (Schedule masking might be a useful feature to have in the future.)

@vpsheth 1 occurrence is correct. When you set an "end_time" then it has a duration. (This is the same as when you have 1 event that spans across a whole week in iCal.) You can check:

```
winter_break.all_occurrences

winter_break.occurring_between?(dec23, dec24) # => true
winter_break.occurring_between?(dec26, dec27) # => true
winter_break.occurring_between?(dec28, dec29) # => true
# ...
```

All of the schedule's occurrences are based on the start time, so if you want occurrences in UTC, you have to give it a UTC start time:

```
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.now.utc) # or
schedule.start_time = Time.now.utc
```

You might also want to look at my [schedule_attributes](https://github.com/avit/schedule_attributes/) gem for going back-and-forth from form inputs. I'm currently working on it, it's not fully documented or released to rubygems, but it works well.

Also, don't use `to_datetime`, DateTime is evil.

But Schedule isn't preserving the timezone of the start time - that's the problem:

```
irb(main):013:0> rule = IceCube::Rule.weekly
=> Weekly
irb(main):014:0> rule.day(4); rule.hour_of_day(12); rule.minute_of_hour(0); rule.second_of_minute(0)

irb(main):018:0> schedule.next_occurrence.utc

I pass in a start time of `CST -06:00`, and `next_occurrence` returns a `Time` with no timezone (so UTC), so Ruby doesn't know it's supposed to be CST. ## 

_~~~~~~~~~~~_
_If it’s important, do it every day; if it’s not important, don’t do it at
all._

This is the more or less the same problem as #127: conflicting rules.

The schedule's occurrences are based on the `start_time`. If you run a daily schedule from "now" (2:58 PM), it will repeat every day at 2:58 PM and return every occurrence that matches this rule. The other stuff you're adding are "validations" for when the daily rule's occurrences will be matched or not. This conflicts:
- Daily starting at 2:58PM on a Tuesday
- But only if it's the 24th hour of the day, the 0 minute and 0 second of the day
- And only if it's Monday

You're never going to find a match for a "next_occurrence" since you can't have "2:58 PM" and "00:00:00" at the same time. 

The weekly rule can figure out "every Monday" starting from a Tuesday, so the day validation is not strictly necessary if you just start your weekly rule on a Monday.

I think you just want:

```
today = Date.today
monday = today - (today.wday - 1)

monday_local = monday.to_time
monday_utc = monday_local.getutc + monday_local.utc_offset 

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(monday_utc) # or monday_local
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly

# or else

schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new(Date.today.to_time)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.weekly.day(1)
```

@forrest Yeah, that looked like a typo. I changed it to read "1st Tuesday and last Tuesday", for now just joining the two with and. There's probably room for improvement by not repeating "Tuesday" (i.e. "first and last Tuesday") but that would be a more general method of composing strings that would apply to all the rules. This fixes it for now.
Thanks

An empty schedule is somewhat pathological, but yes, that seems like the right thing to do... at least keep the representation consistent between:
- to_ical
- to_s
- all_occurrences

My point is that it is not consistent because to_ical clearly shows an event while to_s and all_occurrences do not. According to the RFC setting start time and end time is enough to define an event so, if you want RFC compliance, to_ical is correct but the tracking of occurrences is not.

From the RFC, which is very clear on this point:

> The "DTSTART" property for a "VEVENT" specifies the inclusive start of the event. For recurring events, it also specifies the very first instance in the recurrence set.

And:

> The recurrence set is generated by considering the initial "DTSTART" property along with the "RRULE", "RDATE", "EXDATE" and "EXRULE" properties contained within the iCalendar object. The "DTSTART" property defines the first instance in the recurrence set.

And maybe this library isn't trying to be RFC 2445 compliant but if that's the case it should be stated clearly so people who are looking for that compliance do not waste their time.

Yes, we should try to be consistent with the spec. I think this change should not affect too many people, the following are currently pathological cases:

**Empty schedule**: it's useless without an rtime. We should include the start occurrence.

**A schedule with one rtime that differs from start_time**: who would even do this? Currently, this schedule has one occurrence, _but_ the ical has DTSTART and RTIME, good for two occurrences. We should include the start occurrence to be consistent.

**A schedule with one rtime that matches the start_time**: Currently that's what we do for a single-event occurrence. We should preserve this, but it needs fixing for ical. (This would become functionally equal to an empty schedule.)
1. IceCube::Schedule all_occurrences should have one occurrence for start_time when empty
   
   ```
      expected: [2012-12-12 12:12:12 -0800]
   
           got: [] (using ==)
   ```
2. IceCube::Schedule all_occurrences should have two occurrences with a recurrence time after start_time
   
   ```
      expected: [2012-12-12 12:12:12 -0800, 2013-01-13 01:13:01 -0800]
   
           got: [2013-01-13 01:13:01 -0800] (using ==)
   ```
3. IceCube::Schedule add_recurrence_time raises ArgumentError if the time is before start_time
   `
      expected ArgumentError but nothing was raised
   `
4. IceCube to_ical should not have an rtime that duplicates start time
   
   ```
      expected: "DTSTART:20121212T120000Z"
   
           got: "DTSTART:20121212T120000Z\nRDATE:20121212T120000Z" (using ==)
   ```
5. IceCube::Schedule to_s should show start time for an empty schedule
   
   ```
      expected: "March 20, 2010"
   
           got: "" (using ==)
   ```

The only question I have is item 3: I'm wondering if we should raise an error since it doesn't make sense to add invisible times then strip them out (currently, they show up for ical and to_s but not occurrences). Feedback welcome: is it valid in icalendar to have an RTIME earlier than DTSTART? Possibilities for adding early rtimes (before start_time):
- Accept them, show them consistently in all_occurrences, to_s, to_ical
- Silently drop them
- Raise an error

Thanks for looking into this with me @thoughtafter, can I trouble you to check the RFC for this last question?

Actually, I think I'll reconsider item 3 in its own issue, it has its own set of concerns... but from all I could find on [RDATE](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5545#section-3.8.5.2):

> The "DTSTART" property defines the first instance in the recurrence set.

My interpretation is that nothing should exist before the start time, so we should ignore any earlier times in all representations, whether or not adding them to the schedule is allowed.

I believe you are correct in your interpretation: any occurrences before DTSTART are invalid. The trickier question is what to do about it. I've given it some thought and haven't come to a conclusion. It's hard to imagine how someone could make this happen. However, I wanted to add that there is another solution: 

if RDATE is added that is less than DTSTART change DTSTART to RDATE and add RDATE with previous DTSTART. 

This is the only solution that allows arbitrary RDATES to be added and not get an exception or dates dropped. I'm not saying this is the best solution, part of me thinks an exception is the way to go and leave it up to the user to make sure they get what they want. But it's something to consider.

Your third example is mistaken: _not terminating_ means that it shouldn't have `until(end_time)`. This is correct:

```
schedule_not_terminating = IceCube::Schedule.new(start_time, :end_time => end_time)
schedule_not_terminating.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily

schedule_not_terminating.terminating?
# => false
```

Your other examples are correct:
- no rules means no repeating, so it's terminating.
- using `until` or `count` terminates the rule. If all rules are terminating, then the schedule itself is terminating.

Note, in #99 and #128 we corrected `schedule.end_time` to mean `DTEND` from the icalendar spec: it sets the length/duration of each occurrence, and not when the schedule stops running. This change confused me too. :wink:

So to test if "schedule" is over, I compare "end_time" with the current date?

>  I understand "terminating?" means "schdule" has a end but does not mean that "schedule" is complete.

Correct, "terminating?" just means the schedule has an end _sometime_ because of a rule limit. It doesn't mean it has _already_ terminated. I think the meaning of "terminating?" is clear enough, but you're right: we should have more detail in the rdoc for most of the schedule methods.

>  So to test if "schedule" is over, I compare "end_time" with the current date?

No, `end_time` should be when the first occurrence ends, for example `end_time = start_time + 3600` for a 1-hour event. To check if a schedule is finished try: `schedule.next_occurrence.nil?

EXRULEs have been deprecated and removed from serialization since 0.11, which means that the schedule could behave differently on first setup vs. serialize and reload... I'm considering we restore the serialization or make this more consistent, perhaps with an error.

### Rules of same type

```
schedule.rrules = [Rule.daily.month_of_year(11, 12, 1, 2, 3)]
schedule.exrules = [Rule.daily.month_of_year(1)]
```
This could easily strip out the matching exception rule and collapse it onto the RRULE without an error. It might be easier to just throw an error, especially if there are validations on these rules then they would have to match exactly.

### Rules of different types

These could just be allowed to serialize: I don't see iCalendar RFC getting updated any time soon so the deprecation of EXRULEs is mostly advisory at this point. Being different types, they would not overlap 100% so that nothing is found.

Thoughts?

It helps to understand that a schedule is made up of 4 things:
- recurrence rules
- exception rules
- recurrence times
- exception times

A rule is contained in a schedule; they're not the same thing. (You seem to be confusing these in your problem description.)

It's only when all your rules coalesce into a schedule that you can get the actual occurrences and see what days it occurs on. (For your weekdays example, if you had one rule that repeats weekly on Mon/Wed/Fri and another rule that repeats on the 15th of every month, putting both of these into the same schedule means you'll eventually get _every_ weekday, since the 15th will fall on different days.)

> Schedule.from_yaml(self.schedule).all_occurrences.collect{|a| Date::DAYNAMES[a.wday]}.uniq
> 
> This renders and array of weekdays that are part of the specific rule. I.E. ["Monday", "Wednesday", "Friday"]. Is there a better way to do this?

That doesn't render the weekdays that are part of a "rule", it's the whole schedule. You won't be able to confidently put these back into a rule again.

For the purposes of your form, you'll need to specify the inputs in a way that mirrors the rules (not based on the resulting occurrences of the schedule).

Note, my schedule_attributes is a rewrite of previous versions to make the params hash-to-object mapping code more manageable & flexible... it's still a work in progress. (The README is definitely out of date so don't take anything at its word: best to read the spec examples.)

If you have an hourly rule that needs to be skipped for a whole day, something like this could work:

```
schedule.add_recurrence_rule(Rule.hourly)
schedule.add_exception_rule(Rule.hourly.day_of_month(25).month_of_year(12))
```

It's not perfect since you can't match the year for a single date, but it will filter every December 25. The other option is to add all the occurrences as static exception times:

```
schedule.add_recurrence_rule(Rule.hourly)
extimes = schedule.occurrences_between(Time.new(2012,12,15), Time.new(2012,12, 26))
extimes.each { |t| schedule.add_exception_time(t) }
```

I don't see that it's worth adding a convenience method for the first approach, and the second approach is too static to be covered by any helper.

I'm going to just _guess_ what you're talking about here:  The end_time is not the end time of the occurrence, it's the end time of the _schedule_.  The _duration_ describes how long each occurrence happens for.  Hence they are two distinct things.

@dlee You are correct.

``` ruby
schedule          = IceCube::Schedule.new Time.utc(2012, 10, 1, 12, 0, 0)
schedule.end_time = Time.utc(2012, 12, 1, 12, 0, 0)
schedule.duration = 3600

schedule.to_ical

#=> DTSTART:20121001T120000Z\nDURATION:PT1H\nDTEND:20121201T120000Z
```

According to the [iCal spec](http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/rrule.html), DTEND is the end time of the _first occurrence_ and is what the duration is calculated from:

> The "DTSTART" and "DTEND" property pair or "DTSTART" and "DURATION" property pair, specified within the  iCalendar object defines the first instance of the recurrence.

Therefore they should be mutually exclusive.
Additionally I feel as though calling `Schedule#duration` when `#end_time` has been set, should return the calculated duration rather than returning `nil`.

Honestly, I use IceCube purely in Ruby, not for outputting to iCal so I'm not too familiar with the details of the iCalendar spec. I think @dlee is right about it though: if you read the second paragraph of [RRULE](http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/rrule.html) description, it's pretty clear about DTEND and IceCube seems to be using it differently:
- IceCube uses DTEND and DURATION together. The iCalendar spec calls for using either one alone.
- IceCube uses `end_time` for bounding the schedule, not for the end of the first occurrence (hence, it has a mismatch for the exported DTEND value).

#### Given I want lunch 12:00 to 13:00 every day in December:

```
# @dlee's way
s = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.new(2012, 12, 1, 12, 0, 0))
s.end_time = s.start_time + 3600
s.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily.until(Time.new(2013,1,1))

s.all_occurrences
# => [2012-12-01 12:00:00 -0800]

s.occurring_at? s.start_time
# => true

s.occurring_at? s.start_time + 30
# => false
```

You can see this is limited to only one occurrence, and it has no duration. However, this works:

```
# @avit's way
s = IceCube::Schedule.new(Time.new(2012, 12, 1, 12, 0, 0))
s.end_time = Time.new(2013,1,1)
s.duration = 3600
s.rrule IceCube::Rule.daily

s.all_occurrences
# => [2012-12-01 12:00:00 -0800, ...,  2012-12-31 12:00:00 -0800]

s.occurring_at? s.start_time
# => true

s.occurring_at? s.start_time + 30
# => true
```

The `.to_ical` conversion for @dlee's version looks more correct, it matches the use of DTEND and UNTIL that an event exported from iCal.app would have, but it's not the correct schedule that my version creates in Ruby.

Observe:

``` ruby
ONE_AM  = Time.new(2012,12,1,1,0,0)
FOUR_AM = Time.new(2012,12,1,4,0,0)
YEAR_END = Time.new(2012,12,31,23,59,59.9)

a = IceCube::Schedule.new(ONE_AM)
b = IceCube::Schedule.new(FOUR_AM)

a.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily
b.add_recurrence_rule IceCube::Rule.daily

a.end_time = YEAR_END
b.end_time = YEAR_END

a.conflicts_with?(b)
# => false

a.duration = 4 * 3600
b.duration = 2 * 3600

a.conflicts_with?(b)
# => true
```

Without a duration, the daily occurrences are just instantaneous times so 01:00 and 04:00 don't conflict.

``` ruby
Time.zone = "America/Vancouver"
local_midnight = 1.day.from_now.beginning_of_day # future
# => Thu, 29 Nov 2012 00:00:00 PST -08:00

s = IceCube::Schedule.new(local_midnight)

The above works as expected: `find_occurrences` uses the future start_time (with correct time zone). Now see what happens when we just change the start time to the past:

``` ruby
s.start_time = Time.zone.now.beginning_of_day # past

s.next_occurrences(2)
# => [2012-11-30 00:00:00 +0000, 2012-12-01 00:00:00 +0000]
```

Note the occurrences have shifted by the utc_offset and the times are plain Time objects (without a time zone).

_UPDATE:_ In the process of writing a failing example against your latest code, it looks like you fixed the UTC offset, but the ActiveSupport time zone still shouldn't get dropped whether Time.now is before or after schedule.start_time.

Maybe `TimeUtil.now` should take an optional parameter for the time zone in order to set it correctly and return the right class?

> With ActiveSupport the fix is easy, but with Ruby we'll need a way of generating Time.now accurately in any time zone

I believe I fixed the ActiveSupport conditional, and I was just looking into this for plain Time. It should respect: 
- the start time's local zone if present (for DST)
- the start time's `utc_offset` when not in `utc`

Currently these are respected when `start_time` is in the future, but not after the schedule has started. I'm adding some example specs to cover this.

Note, DST won't be respected when the time isn't local to the current system zone, so shifting to other zones can't be done without ActiveSupport:

``` ruby
start_time = Time.new(2012, 7, 1) # => 2012-07-01 00:00:00 -0700
start_time.zone # => "PDT"
start_time.dst? # => true

start_time.localtime("-05:00") # => 2012-07-01 02:00:00 -0500
start_time.zone # => nil
start_time.dst? # => false

start_time.localtime # => 2012-07-01 00:00:00 -0700
start_time.zone # => "PDT"
start_time.dst? # => true
```

> start = DateTime.now.change(month: month, year: year).beginning_of_month
> finish = DateTime.now.change(month: month, year: year).end_of_month

What are the values of `month` and `year` that you are changing here?

It looks like the problem is in TimeUtil not handling DateTime correctly because DateTime adds by days, not seconds. Note the difference between:

```
Time.local(2012, 12, 21) + 1   # => 2012-12-21 00:00:01
DateTime.new(2012, 12, 21) + 1 # => 2012-12-22 00:00:00
```

Hence, when we add `interval * ONE_DAY` we get the wrong jump.

I recently made it so that whatever value the `schedule.start_time` is set to, the occurrence methods would always return the same class (plain Time or ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone or DateTime). Doing this found & fixed some other problems related to DateTime but I'm now wondering whether DateTime should even be supported as a `start_time` value, and just put up a warning while converting it to Time, because:
- DateTime behaves more Date-like than Time-like (it just happens to have time-of-day attributes but that's about it)
- it has an inconsistent interface and lacks all the usual methods for calculating & querying
- it's magnitudes slower

It would take some workarounds to properly support DateTime transparently:
- Retain DateTime value in start_time
- Internally convert to Time for all calculations
- Convert occurrences back to `start_time.class` (DateTime) for output

I don't believe this has any benefit. Is there any valid use case for DateTime? 

I vote to remove support by converting `to_time` with warning. Any thoughts, @seejohnrun?

(By the way, I posted an [answer on StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/a/14007547/61439) that covers the different ruby time classes. I tried to show why DateTime is dumb.)

Well I imagine you could do a more general api like `offset_from_day(offset, date or block(year))` where the block could be used to do arbitrary calculations. So what I sticked into time_utils could be applied directly. However that would mean it wouldn't be easily serializable, defeating the whole purpose.

The more ambitious way would be to have a `register_user_validation("serialization key", num_arguments, class)` where you could plugin any class (so I would write something like `offset_from_pascha.rb` and call `IceCube.register_user_validation("offset_from_pascha", 2, MyApp::OffsetFromPascha)`, and the rest would be taken care of for me).

This is really neat, but I think we should close this pull request. Hopefully someone can find your fork here if they need it, or you can offer it as a separate plugin.

I agree that this should be more abstract & pluggable, but IceCube also needs to be compatible with the iCalendar RFC for serializing. Unfortunately the spec provides nothing for such custom rules. (Both in terms of varying dates year-over-year and offsetting from a date.)

Okay - so I'm about to put in a fix for this, but I want to write up a bit about what's going on and some expected caveats, which come as a result of iCalendar's specification

If you specify a recurring rule with IceCube as you have, you will end up with no occurrence in your time zone on the date when jumping back over DST (the 31st), since that time _does not exist_ at that hour.  Its easy to jump through time at regular intervals, harder to try to repeat events at a consistent time each day when the time you're repeating on isn't always there.

That being said, the hanging is fixed.  It will go out with v0.9.0 likely tomorrow afternoon after I remove the deprecations and integrate a few more fixes

---

Really, issues like this are the heart of what make this library so compelling - there are countless issues with DST, TZ, weekdays, and month lengths that had to be figured out to make any of this work.  My apologies for the hanging and the delay

Much appreciated - IceCube is designed with a lot of optimizations around the generation of dates.  The interaction supplied by `find_occurrences` is extremely performant.

The problem with `conflicts_with?` and `occurs_on?` is that the insane unrealistic requirements that iCalendar RFC puts on libraries like IceCube (which tries to be backward compatible to that RFC).  The problem becomes: what data structure could you efficiently query (other than a lookup table by second) to determine whether a rule like every 13th and 14th second of the 5th hour starting now but in 2025 occurs at a given time.

We ended up using IceCube to generate data to populate a `schedule_occurrences` table that we used to answer questions like "what events occur on these dates", "does this event occur at this time", etc.

---

That being said, without complex rules (especially `count`, `day_of_week`s, and non-1 `interval`s which have to always be fully processed from `start_time` due to their nature), IceCube attempts to skip iterating through time and jump by calculating via time offsets.  That's how its able to be so fast at generating dates

If you don't use any of those three devices, I'd love to hear more detail on an individual example that is slow - maybe some code?
If anyone has some code they'd expect to be performant given the stipulations mentioned above, please open a new ticket - thanks!

schedule.next_occurrences(12).each do |occurrence|

    occurrence = occurrence.without_ms

    if !schedule.extimes.map(&:to_i).include? occurrence.to_i
       # Okay, the occurrence is not in our extimes list
    end
 end

I think I found the issue. But I am not sure whether this is intended.

```
require 'rubygems'
require 'ice_cube'
require 'active_support/all'
require 'pp'
include IceCube

schedule = Schedule.new(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily.hour_of_day(8)
pp schedule.occurrences_between(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 20), DateTime.new(2012, 05, 22))
```

Schedule and finding occurrences is heavily tied to the given Time. 
In the above example, the last occurrences will not print 20th May 08:00, 21st May 08:00. 

However, if I change the code to be 

```
require 'rubygems'
require 'ice_cube'
require 'active_support/all'
require 'pp'
include IceCube

schedule = Schedule.new(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 1))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily.hour_of_day(8)
pp schedule.occurrences_between(DateTime.new(2012, 05, 20, 8, 0, 0), DateTime.new(2012, 05, 22, 8, 0, 0))
```

the occurrences are printed fine. Generally Schedules are created somewhere and passed around. The user of this Schedule will not know how to query it using the right Time Offset. It looks like IceCube validates something like that.

Moreover, if I look into schedule.rb and find_occurrences, it starts from the given start_time passed to find_occurrences and checks whether the given time matches with the rule. However, find_occurrences is supposed to give all occurrnces between the given two times.
Regression test added - also make sure you're using `Time` or converting to `Time` (not `DateTime`) when using IceCube - you could run into some unexpected issues
This should be fixed in `master` now, and will be pushed out with v0.9.0 tomorrow afternoon

Check out https://github.com/bokmann/business_time

Actually you can do this with `IceCube` but you will need to create multiple schedules. iCalendar only supports one start and end time per event (regardless of whether it recurs or not). So you will need to use a model with a has_and_belongs_to_many association to another model that represents the schedule objects.

I have the same requirements. Glancing at the [iCalendar spec](http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/rrule.html), I don't see any built-in provision for simple date ranges like:

**Daily between October 15 and April 15 (...every year)**

I'm having to find a way to work around this, so if anyone can point out a better possibility I'd appreciate it.

One (somewhat ridiculous) approach:

```
range = Date.new(2012,10,15) .. Date.new(2013,04,15)
days = if range.first.yday > range.last.yday
  (1..range.last.yday).to_a + (range.first.yday..365).to_a << -1
else
   range.first.yday..range.last.yday
end
schedule = IceCube::Schedule.new
schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.yearly.day_of_year(*days))
```

This gives the right recurrences (not minding leap years), but the representation is messy:

_Yearly on the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, 14th, 15th, 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, 23rd, 24th, 25th, 26th, 27th, 28th, 29th, 30th, 31st, 32nd, 33rd, 34th, 35th, 36th, 37th, 38th, 39th, 40th, 41st, 42nd, 43rd, 44th, 45th, 46th, 47th, 48th, 49th, 50th, 51st, 52nd, 53rd, 54th, 55th, 56th, 57th, 58th, 59th, 60th, 61st, 62nd, 63rd, 64th, 65th, 66th, 67th, 68th, 69th, 70th, 71st, 72nd, 73rd, 74th, 75th, 76th, 77th, 78th, 79th, 80th, 81st, 82nd, 83rd, 84th, 85th, 86th, 87th, 88th, 89th, 90th, 91st, 92nd, 93rd, 94th, 95th, 96th, 97th, 98th, 99th, 100th, 101st, 102nd, 103rd, 104th, 105th, 289th, 290th, 291st, 292nd, 293rd, 294th, 295th, 296th, 297th, 298th, 299th, 300th, 301st, 302nd, 303rd, 304th, 305th, 306th, 307th, 308th, 309th, 310th, 311st, 312nd, 313rd, 314th, 315th, 316th, 317th, 318th, 319th, 320th, 321st, 322nd, 323rd, 324th, 325th, 326th, 327th, 328th, 329th, 330th, 331st, 332nd, 333rd, 334th, 335th, 336th, 337th, 338th, 339th, 340th, 341st, 342nd, 343rd, 344th, 345th, 346th, 347th, 348th, 349th, 350th, 351st, 352nd, 353rd, 354th, 355th, 356th, 357th, 358th, 359th, 360th, 361st, 362nd, 363rd, 364th, 365th, and last days of the year_

Another possibility using exception rules to mask the dates from the first and last months:

```
range = Date.new(2012,10,15) .. Date.new(2013,04,15)
months = range.group_by(&:month).keys
schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.daily.month_of_year(*months))
unless range.first.day == 1
  first_days = IceCube::Rule.yearly.month_of_year(range.first.month).day_of_month(*1...range.first.day)
  schedule.add_exception_rule(first_days)
end
unless range.last.day >= 30
  last_days = IceCube::Rule.yearly.month_of_year(range.last.month).day_of_month(*(range.last.day+1)..31)
  schedule.add_exception_rule(last_days)
end
```

_Daily in October, November, December, January, February, March, and April 
/ not Yearly in October on the 1st, 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 5th, 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, and 14th days of the month 
/ not Yearly in April on the 16th, 17th, 18th, 19th, 20th, 21st, 22nd, 23rd, 24th, 25th, 26th, 27th, 28th, 29th, 30th, and 31st days of the month_

As far as the original question, @reedlaw has it right.  iCalendar is a standard, yet fairly weak at describing recurrence rules like this. IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(-1)

I have the user input a day of the month, so I do it like this...

```
    if start_time.day == start_time.end_of_month.day
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(-1))
    elsif start_time.day > 28
      // using -1 here on Feb, catches leap years too
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(start_time.day))
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.yearly.month_of_year(:february).day_of_month(-1))
    else
      schedule.add_recurrence_rule(IceCube::Rule.monthly.day_of_month(start_time.day))
    end
```

My first idea was indeed to split weekst away from WeeklyInterval in its own Validation. The problem is that they are really tightly coupled. The way dates are calculated in WeeklyInterval needs to be overwritten when you take weekst into account. Furthermore, if you take sunday as the default weekst (the way it is in ice_cube), the weekst attribute has to be present in the iCal export, since the standard defines that the default weekst is monday. When you define weekst in a separate validation, the user always has the option not to include it, and the iCal export will be wrong.

About the serialization, you are right, it should be a number. We will fix that.
The option IceCube::Rule.weekly(2, :monday) was already implemented apparently, so I just changed the docs to use the same API as the rest of the examples. Week start is now serialized as a number.
I noticed, that (de)serialization with to/from yaml doesn't support week start as well. Does this fix that issue too?

@masquita, I rebased your changes on master to do a little cleanup (whitespace, method names, etc.) and pulled this in. The API for `weekly(1, :sunday)` might look a little confusing vs. `weekly(1).day(:sunday)`, but it works.

This is indeed an issue. Europe for one in general uses Monday as the first weekday. What makes matters worse is when you export the recurring rules to iCal. If not specified on the RRULE, iCal will take a wild guess and base its interpretation on the regional settings in the System Preferences. This leads to inconsistencies between the occurrences ice_cube puts out and what appears in iCal.

For the future - since ice_cube wants to keep backward compatible with the iCalendar standard, there are two ways to accomplish something like this:
1.  Multiple schedules for before and after those days
2.  Exception rules for those days (recommended if you only have a few rules)
3.  Handling this logic of starting and stopping outside of the Schedule object

No not the last day, here's an example:

I create a new task on the 30th January, and want it to repeat every month on the same day. However, because February only goes to 28 (29 on a leap year) I want it to be the last day of February.

Here's another example:

I create a new task on the 31st of January, and want it to repeat monthly. But for every month that has less than 31 days, I want it to be on the last day of every month.

So I've got around it by checking to see if the day is greater than 28, and if it is, adding a separate rule for february.
But first I check if the day chosen is the end of the month, and just use the day_of_month(-1) rule

It works with Time, not with Date or DateTime.

With this code it works (params[:schedule][:next] comes from a date form):

``` ruby
datetime = DateTime.civil(params[:schedule]["next(1i)"].to_i, params[:schedule]["next(2i)"].to_i, params[:schedule]["next(3i)"].to_i)
tmp.start_date = Time.parse(datetime.strftime("%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S %z"))
```

You can also do it this way

``` ruby
hash = schedule.to_hash
schedule = Schedule.from_hash(hash, :start_date_override => Time.now)
```

[AFAICS] It really is a matter of the dreaded 'time_zone' - you can create schedules like this

```
schedule=IceCube::Schedule.new( DateTime.new(2012,4,1,14,0,0).in_time_zone(-2)  )
=>  
ruby-1.9.2-p290 :040 > schedule.to_hash
=> {:start_date=>{:time=>Sun, 01 Apr 2012 14:00:00 +0000, :zone=>"Mid-Atlantic"}, :rrules=>[], :exrules=>[], :rtimes=>[], :extimes=>[]} 
```

Whoever decided that we should live in 24 time_zones obviously did not have to programme the darn bugger ;)
I like to think that even though it is a MF*ing pain in something, Core Team is on the right track with the ActiveSupport::TimeWithZone - it's just the rest of us having to adjust :)

If you drop the argument to .in_time_zone it will grab your default (on the server/your development env)

You can use Date.new(y,m,d).to_datetime.in_time_zone - if all you have is a date :)

Probably the preferred way to handle this behavior is with a ruby splat:

``` ruby
arr = [1, 2, 3]
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.day(*arr)
```

If you don't know whether its an array, you can be more explicit:

``` ruby
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rulle.day(arr.is_a?(Enumerable) ? *arr : arr)
```

The examples are non-functional, at least in 1.9.2.   I don't know of a compelling reason to not apply the patch since the performance impact of flatten() should be negligible, but it's obviously ultimately your call.

which examples are non-functional?  sorry for the confusion - just want to make sure I understand

Calling the methods with a splat should work, since these two are the same:

``` ruby
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.day(*[1, 2, 3])
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.day(1, 2, 3)
```

So you can pass an array in by using the splat operator on it:

``` ruby
arr = [1, 2, 3]
schedule.rrule IceCube::Rule.day(*arr)
```

I'm experiencing the same behavior with 0.7.6, and I think I know why at least for my case. I'm adding a recurrence rule just like above, but for my exception I specified just a date, instead of a date with time. If I include the exact time of the originally scheduled occurrence then everything works fine, and the occurrence is excluded. 

I don't know if this is the desired behavior or not. If it is, having the alias Schedule#add_exception_date is a bit misleading, as the only way you can exclude an occurrence is by specifying the exact date and time.

It looks like the problem is in either SingleOccurrenceRule#next_time or Rule#on? `next_time` returns the exact date/time of the event, while `on?` tries to match exactly to the exception value. Which of course means if you use just a date, it will fail. I could be completely wrong though. I just did a quick glance at the code, and that jumped out, but I might be missing something somewhere else.

The name is misleading, and in the next version `add_exception_date` will be deprecated in favor of `add_exception_time` which you can use now.

ical doesn't support adding exception for an entire date, but if you don't use any time-wise rules it should work as desired if you set the exception time to have the same time segment as your start_time

I've done a little digging. 

## Firstly I agree that I see the same result as you are seeing.

The docs are indeed a little confusing. This comment implies that there should be an occurrence for every day in may

```
# Create a schedule for every day in May
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.now)
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.daily.month_of_year(:may)
```

While this line implies that the behaviour you are seeing (once a year on the start day) is what happens.

   # When are the first 10 occurrences
   schedule.first(10) # [Thu May 13 18:01:46 -0400 2010, Fri May 13 ...]

## So what should the behaviour be?

The iCal spec has a similar example (from here: http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/rrule.html#example)

```
Everyday in January, for 3 years:

DTSTART;TZID=US-Eastern:19980101T090000

RRULE:FREQ=YEARLY;UNTIL=20000131T090000Z;
  BYMONTH=1;BYDAY=SU,MO,TU,WE,TH,FR,SA
or
RRULE:FREQ=DAILY;UNTIL=20000131T090000Z;BYMONTH=1

==> (1998 9:00 AM EDT)January 1-31
    (1999 9:00 AM EDT)January 1-31
    (2000 9:00 AM EDT)January 1-31
```

So it seems the same rule can be expressed in two different ways in iCal. With exactly the same output.

### So reproducing this example in a number of ways using ice_cube

#### Reproducing it like in the issue, we get the wrong behaviour

```
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.local(1998,01,01,9,0))
rule = Rule.daily.month_of_year(:january).until(Time.local(2000,01,31,9,0))
rule.to_ical 
  #=> "FREQ=DAILY;BYMONTH=1;UNTIL=Mon Jan 31 09:00:00 +0000 2000"

#This seems to be the same as the spec, but:

schedule.add_recurrence_rule(rule)
schedule.first(10) 
  #=> [Thu Jan 01 00:00:00 +0000 1998, Fri Jan 01 00:00:00 +0000 1999, Sat Jan 01 00:00:00 +0000 2000, Mon Jan 01 00:00:00 +0000 2001, Tue Jan 01 00:00:00 +0000 2002...]
  # this is not the same as the spec
```

#### However, if we reproduce the first example from the iCal spec, it works

```
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.local(1998,01,01,9,0))
rule = Rule.yearly.day(0,1,2,3,4,5,6).month_of_year(:january).until(Time.local(2000,01,31,9,0))
rule.to_ical
  #=> "FREQ=YEARLY;BYDAY=SU,MO,TU,WE,TH,FR,SA;BYMONTH=1"

schedule.add_recurrence_rule(rule)
schedule.first(10)
  #=> [Thu Jan 01 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Fri Jan 02 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Sat Jan 03 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Sun Jan 04 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Mon Jan 05 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Tue Jan 06 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Wed Jan 07 09:00:00 +0000 1998, Thu Jan 08 09:00:00 +0000 1998...]
  # this is correct
```

- The behaviour for "Daily in May" differs from the iCal spec for the same iCal rule for some rules.

It's happening because Daylights Savings Time ends, which in turn confuses DayOfWeek#closest(date)

----DayOfWeek: goal Sat Nov 05 00:00:00 -0500 2011
----DayOfWeek: goal Sun Nov 06 00:00:00 -0500 2011
----DayOfWeek: goal Sun Nov 06 23:00:00 -0600 2011
----DayOfWeek: goal Mon Nov 07 23:00:00 -0600 2011
--------Validation: goal Mon Nov 07 23:00:00 -0600 2011
--------Validation: goal adjusted Tue Nov 08 00:00:00 -0600 2011

Quick update on this matter: the duration attribute need to be converted to "minutes". The example above return the following i_cal transformation: ``` DTSTART;TZID=BRST:20111116T150833\nDURATION:PT11M30S\nRRULE:FREQ=WEEKLY;BYDAY=TU;BYHOUR=10;BYMINUTE=30 ``` The parameter: DURATION got the value: PT11M30S, that checking on iCal RFC (http://www.kanzaki.com/docs/ical/duration-t.html) represents 11 minutes and 30 seconds :D Maybe that need to be updated inside the documentation? So for example, I have a "Group" model that "has_many :activities". I need to create a form for a user to input a "weekly recurring activity" then convert that into something I can store in the database. Then when I need to display the activities for that "Group" model, I need to convert that data that was stored in the database into something human readable.

So the two biggest parts I'm having trouble with are creating a form to add a "recurrence rule", and converting the "schedule.from_yaml()" into a human readable list or table view.

Any advice in regards to those two topics in particular?

Thanks!

What will end up happening is that you'll create the form however is natural
for you, and have a controller action that gets the data back and moves it
into an ice_cube schedule.

Once its an ice_cube schedule, you can store the to_yaml in the database.

To go back to human readable you can either call schedule.to_s, or iterate
over the schedule#rrules, and call to_s on each of those.  You'll get
schedule by using `schedule = Schedule.from_yaml(yaml_from_db)

hope this helps,
JC

next_occurrence expects to get the from time, and it defaults to Time.now.  Hence the failure.  Should be

schedule.next_occurrence(start_time)

or

schedule.next_occurrences(3, start_time)

I may be missing something, but I think the behavior here is correct.

```
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.local(2010, 6, 29))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_week :tuesday => [-1]
schedule.occurrences_between(Time.local(2010, 7, 1), Time.local(2010, 8, 1))
```

Should _not_ return Time.local(2010, 6, 29), since it falls out of the range of Time.local(2010, 7, 1) and Time.local(2010, 8, 1)

For the behavior you'd expect, you can use the .occurrences method instead:

```
schedule = Schedule.new(Time.local(2010, 6, 29))
schedule.add_recurrence_rule Rule.monthly.day_of_week :tuesday => [-1]
schedule.occurrences(Time.local(2010, 8, 1))
```

which will give you all of the occurrences until a certain time, in this case:

```
[Time.local(2010, 6, 29, 10, 0, 0), Time.local(2010, 7, 27, 10, 0, 0)]
```

Hope this helps, let me know if I missed something - I'll leave the ticket open for a few days

The problem is that the duration of the event is 3 days, so if the event starts on 6/29, it goes through 7/1.  If you do schedule.occurring_at? Time.local(2010, 7, 1), you'll get true, which is what you would expect, but when you query for occurrences between 7/1 and 8/1, you don't get it, which is what I think the bug is.

Ah, gotcha - I'm a bit torn on this:

occurrences_between should only return occurrences that start in that time period.
I can imagine people having uses for both cases though.. people may want to only look for occurrences that haven't already started.

Maybe, the way to make the call you want is:

```
schedule.occurrences_between(Time.local(2010, 6, 29, 10) - schedule.duration, Time.local(2010, 7, 27, 10))
```

Let me know what ya think

Has this made it's way into the current release? As I skimmed through the library, it doesn't look like it's made an appearance. 

If not, I definitely +1 the option to include dates if they fall within the specified duration.

ice_cube doesn't handle time ranges, just occurrences.  Even if you added every second between 11:15am and 12:45pm, you'd still run into issues because of usec(s).  

I would use ice_cube occurs_on? to see if it occurs on a given date, and then make sure that its in the desired time range.

I've added the ability to set durations on a schedule.  Since we need to stick with how iCal represents dates (so that to_ical works properly), it needs to be at the schedule level instead of the rule level.

```

dynamically generates itself upon umport.

> import the module. This cannot be right, and causes huge issues. On
> our buildserver for example there is no network-manager running and
> your nice library NetworkManager cannot even be imported, even though

> imports it.

That's a bug in your tests. If you don't use NetworkManager, don't
import python-networkmanager.

D.

Thanks for your quick reply. :+1:

Let's make more relevant comparisions on how modules are implemented in python. I chose a few I've been using, that also communicate with other parts, just like python-networkmanager.
- pyserial - Possible to import module without any serial device connected.
- requests - Possible to import library without internet connection.

What these have in common is that you can import the module regardless of whether you will later be able to call the functions. In this company python-networkmanager unfortunately stick out as less pleasant to use.

Let's assume my tests _are_ broken. How would a good test look according to you? Realize there is no way to mock NetworkManager as it cannot even be imported.

I understand you want singleton semantics, so that multiple objects cannot be created. But please consider this, perhaps there is some good solution you would be happy with?

Your comparison is quite flawed. pyserial/requests communicate with non-local things, be it internet hosts or a serial device. The NetworkManager module only communicates with a local NetworkManager instance. If you're not running NetworkManager, you should not use this module.

This get's even more problematic when you consider signals. Now you have to call some mainloop function stuff _before_ importing NetworkManager? I'm sorry but this does not make any sense. Normally you _first_ import all your stuff and then execute code.

I think it's time you familiarize yourself more with dbus. What you wrote there is definitely incorrect. You'll need to set up the mainloop before trying to do anything asynchronous (like listening to signals, which auto_reconnect does), not before you import things. The whole reason auto_reconnect is a function you need to call separately is to avoid having to set up a mainloop before importing NetworkManager.

Actually if you look at [examples/listener.py:5](https://github.com/seveas/python-networkmanager/blob/master/examples/listener.py#L5) you can see the statement `dbus.mainloop.glib.DBusGMainLoop(set_as_default=True)`being called right after `dbus` is important. This is not optional, but needs to be called after dbus import but before NetworkManager import. All those weird import dependencies with need to call methods in between, makes it a hassle to use. Not to mention that all this needs a `try` wrap around it. Anyway, I though of a way of doing this in an opt-in way, e.g. current users of this lib won't be affected by the change, but if you want a slicker way of importing NetworkManager that will be possoble. Please at least consider it. Sometimes it easier to explain things in code rather than in words. :-)
Nope. That call does not necessarily need to be there, it just needs to be done before any async dbus functionality is used. I like to put it right after the import, but that is not necessary.
Nope. Please try things before speculating wildly. Just tried that on fairly fresh Ubuntu 16.04. Anyway. a pr suggestion coming your way shortly. Bon appetite :-)

The traceback of error:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):  
  File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/NetworkManager.py", line 117, in proxy_call
    ret = func(*args, **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dbus/proxies.py", line 145, in __call__
    **keywords)
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/dbus/connection.py", line 651, in call_blocking
    message, timeout)
dbus.exceptions.DBusException: org.freedesktop.DBus.Error.ServiceUnknown: The name :1.188 was not provided by any .service files
```
The only way to recover from this is to reload the module and reassign device and connections.

In 1.2, released just the other day, I implemented a solution for this. You will need to call the auto_reconnect() method of the NetworkManager object at the start of your program. Do note that this requires your application to be run in a mainloop instead of using sleep, as good dbus citizens are required to.

You can find an example of how to use this on https://github.com/seveas/dotfiles/blob/master/bin/autovpn

@seveas in my code I have chunks of blocking code, for instance scanning for networks, sleeping for few seconds after switching connections. which are kind of 'sleep' routines. Are these going to affect the dbus communications?
Yes, you'll want to avoid sleeps and use [events and timers](https://developer.gnome.org/pygobject/stable/glib-functions.html) instead. Sleeps and mainloops are not friends.
Yikes, that's a pretty stupid bug, thanks!

This is just whitespace churn. pep-8 is not a holy grail, merely a guideline.

At least for me the problem is solved by the following patch. May be it should be mainlined...

```
From 5e5eb6345494d3b07568e9064c9841b8c90e43d4 Mon Sep 17 00:00:00 2001
From: Adrian <adrian.freihofer@gmail.com>
Date: Tue, 6 Jan 2015 15:38:15 +0100
Subject: [PATCH] Ignore empty dict

Signed-off-by: Adrian <adrian.freihofer@gmail.com>
---
 NetworkManager.py | 2 +-
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+), 1 deletion(-)

diff --git a/NetworkManager.py b/NetworkManager.py
index 7865702..84020b5 100644
--- a/NetworkManager.py
+++ b/NetworkManager.py
@@ -94,7 +94,7 @@ class NMDbusInterface(object):
                     return val
         if hasattr(val, '__iter__') and not isinstance(val, basestring):
             if hasattr(val, 'items'):
-                return dict([(x, self.wrap(y)) for x, y in val.items()])
+                return dict([(x, self.wrap(y)) for x, y in val.items() if not (isinstance(y, (list, dict)) and not y)])
             else:
                 return [self.wrap(x) for x in val]
         return val
-- 
1.9.1
```

I don't like that idea very much. Why not incorporate your function that properly wraps `{}` and `[]`? That way everybody benefits :)

I agree, it's not a perfect solution. That's the reason why I did not publish it until somebody asked for it.
However, the empty dict is generated by NetworkManager itself. The following flow seems to be quite common but ends up in an exception:
- read configuration from NetworkManager
- modify the configuration
- write the configuration back to NetworkManager.

The problem is the "u's390-options': {}" object which we get from NetworkManager. This triggers an exception if it is written back to NetworkManager.
The question is: Where is the right place to filter for objects in configurations which are provided by NetworkManager but not understood by NetworkManager?

git-hub would rather not know your username and password at all :smile: It asks for them only once: to create a token for further authentication, this token is then stored either in a file, or in your configured credential helper.

Passing a username and password on the commandline is insecure in shared environments: everybody can read those while the process is running. Reading the username and password from a file would mean that they need to be in a file in the first place, which I'd rather avoid too. The token already ends up in a file.

Yes, they do. They prefix all anchors with `user-content-`, even manually inserted <a/> tags are rewritten. https://assets-cdn.github.com/assets/github-bb7365e507a4c75141f5e042c5d5a4b321094bfb2e9aa23ddf004604c7109ef5.js then does the magic with an on-click listener that makes the links work. Well, I guess it would at least give the browser a chance to render it. But if you have maaany tabs open and Firefox needs to start first, it can need a quite long sleep. Why not let the file sitting there in the temporary directory? If you are concerned about filling up diskspace, you could add some logic so that if you call render the next time all generated files that are older than X are deleted. If you e. g. want to look at the generated HTML with `Ctrl+U` it is also unhandy if the file is not present anylonger.

If firefox needs to start, webbrowser.open() doesn't return until it has started, so the sleep(1) is sufficient there. It's only when firefox is already running, that webbrowser.open() returns before firefox even attempts to open the file.

Hm, interesting. It is less a problem of timeout. FF just won't render the file from the temp directory. If I move it somewhere else it renders it, if it is in the temp folder it refuses to render anything
No, it is not about the folder. If I copy the file in the same folder it is rendered fine
More probably some issue with the tempfile mechanism that is used

>  tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile([mode='w+b'[, bufsize=-1[, suffix=''[, prefix='tmp'[, dir=None[, delete=True]]]]]])
> 
>    This function operates exactly as TemporaryFile() does, except that the file is guaranteed to have a visible name in the file system (on Unix, the directory entry is not unlinked). That name can be retrieved from the name attribute of the returned file-like object. **Whether the name can be used to open the file a second time, while the named temporary file is still open, varies across platforms (it can be so used on Unix; _it cannot on Windows NT or later_)**. If delete is true (the default), the file is deleted as soon as it is closed.
Thanks for that, I completely missed or forgot that. Will rethink how this is done, ideas welcome. Ideally something that auto-cleans.

This works for me:

```
with tempfile.NamedTemporaryFile(suffix='.html', delete=False) as fd:
    fd.write(html.encode('utf-8'))
    fd.close()
    webbrowser.open('file://' + fd.name)
    time.sleep(1)
    os.remove(fd.name)
```

While of course it still does not allow viewing the source of the file, but for that you can still use --save as fallback or use Firebug to some extent.

To install the latest released version on other systems, assuming python and

    sudo pip install git-spindle
```

Try 3 - I removed the editor line, to let it launch the default one. But this time a windows error appeared saying app should be run as non-elevated user, which I see is a issue with Gitpad itself and also happens when I use git commit without editor set. Will resolve it separately.

But what to do if you have a `editor = something` set?

Update:

I finally managed to get it working, by including the wordpad path to env. I think this was very much a corner case as apparently `cmd` on windows doesnt know the path of wordpad automatically, which is where `shell=true` redirects, but `powershell` knows it automatically even when it is not in the env path.

**So, not at all a mistake from `git-spindle`. It is fixed.** :smiley:

**But I think there is another interesting thing too:**

I saw that `_getitem` tries all env path and also append `.exe` to search for the file on Windows, but when I used just `editor=wordpad` i.e. without the `.exe`, it never actually reached that function. First `_call_` tries to resolve it via popen and just fails, so without `.exe` it will probably never actually reach that `.exe` adding stuff.
Intriguing. I can reproduce that here. Looks like it clones the right thing, but then set-origin gets confused.

Solution:
- set_origin needs to be less dwim-y (don't try to find a repo in your account)
- fork, clone etc. need to pass a repo to set_origin so it doesn't need the dwimness

Ok. So for Fedora 21 at least ~/.local/share/bash-completion/completions/ is actually loaded (without adding extra stuff to my bashrc). However it only loads completion files there matching them with the executable name. So for example if i add a script called "pip" there it would complete against the "pip" command. This will never work for git subcommands though. 

Hm... _looks further_

Hm. It seems like `/etc/bash_completion.d/` is fairly widely supported for just autoloading a bunch of scripts (without the auto-loading stuff that happens under `/usr/share/bash-completion/completions/`).

I'm not very familiar with python and setup.py, but if it's possible my suggestion is to install into `/etc/bash_completion.d/` when doing a system install and under ~/.config/bash_completion.d/ on a `--user` install. And then in the docs say that you need to add something like the below to your .bashrc.

```
for comp in ${HOME}/.config/bash_completion.d/ /* ; do
    if [ -f "${comp}" ] ; then
        . $comp
    fi
done
```

Either that or just install it _somewhere_ and say that people need to symlink it to whatever directory they use for their completion scripts.

Intriguing. Is this actually on gitlab.com or on your own instance? The title (your email address) should be in `pkey.title`, not `pkey.key`.

This is our own server (GitLab 7.10.0), however I don't think that's significant. The value of `pkey.key` is exactly what I imported into GitLab (copied from my `~/.ssh/id_rsa.pub`), and this includes my e-mail address. This is standard OpenSSH format.

I know it is the standard OpenSSH, but the GitLab api is not supposed to return it that way. The algorithm and key parts go in `pkey.key` and the title part goes in `pkey.title`. gitlab.com and gitlab 7.7.2 on my own server both do that, so I guess this is a new bug in 7.10.

Does `pkey.title` actually contain anything for your key?
Does git lab public-keys work for you?

Yes, `pkey.title` is also my e-mail address.

When you add a key in the GitLab GUI there are 'Title' and 'Key' boxes to fill in, so I'm guessing that `pkey.title` is returning what I entered in the 'Title' field, which was my e-mail address, and `pkey.key` is returning what I put in the 'Key' field, which was the whole of the public key.

I'm not a big fan of $XDG_CONFIG_HOME, so I haven't actually looked at the downsides of doing this. Won't this break on e.g. osx and windows?

...ouch. Can't believe I forgot that.

That said, neither git nor gitk themselves seem to care either, at least from reading the commits I've linked. If the environment variable is empty, nothing breaks – it'll use the spec-defined default, `~/.config/git/`. (That's the case on most Linux systems too.)

On Windows (with Cygwin) and FooBSDs, many users likely already have programs using `~/.config/` too. (Dotfiles aren't a Windows thing anyway. It would be ideal to use AppData I guess.)

On OS X, the new path is just a little bit unusual. (Unfortunately I don't know what paths _are_ usual...)
- I could add a whitelist or blacklist for `os.name == "posix"` or similar.
- I could swap the order so that `~/.gitspindle` remains the default in new installations, with `~/.config/git/spindle` as the fallback path.
- I could make it use `%APPDATA%` on Windows, and [something] on OS X.
- I don't want to withdraw the patch unless it's explicitly rejected. (Even though more and more programs migrate to ~/.config and ~/.cache, I still have 5× ~/.dotfiles than regular files, and I'd like to clean them up.)
Can we somehow get git to tell us what config file it uses? Then we can use that to calculate our path :)

Regarding OSX I think the default folder for config files like these are `~/Library/` which would mean `~/Library/git/spindle.conf` I guess. However since `git` doesn't integrate with default settings folders on any system except for Linux I'd say just follow their example (which is what @grawity 's patch does).

EDIT: did a quick search and couldn't find any other way to find the path to the local git config than just re-implementing the logic git does (which to be fair isn't very complex).

The logic in git is the other way around than what this patch is proposing: $XDG_CONFIG_HOME/.git/config is only used if it already exists. Otherwise ~/.gitconfig is used. So on a system where neither exists, ~/.gitconfig is used. I will implement the same logic as what git does, thus rejecting this PR.

- Branch does not exist? Offer to push.
- Branch is simply behind? Offer to push.
- Branch has diverged and needs push -f? Offer to push -f

Yeah, I'm afraid that this is outside python-hpilo's control. More and more os'es and python distributions drop support for older ssl/tls versions. You'll need to use an older python version and maybe even an older os (to get an older openssl) to upgrade your ilo firmware to a version that supports modern tls versions.

I've traced it back to this line that was added somewhere between v4.3 and v4.4.1:
https://github.com/seveas/python-hpilo/blob/8880f692d347e1ac7d0b0de993325d70b69c38aa/hpilo.py#L403

It's problematic on e.g. `Python 3.9.0` on MacOS, where using the above code results in this ssl.SSLError: `('No cipher can be selected.',)`, but changing that line the following way (to drop "RC4-SHA") makes it work again:
```diff
-self.ssl_context.set_ciphers("RC4-SHA:" + ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
+self.ssl_context.set_ciphers(ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
```

I don't fully understand why Python/SSL simply won't ignore this cipher that it maybe doesn't support in that version. [Documentation](https://docs.python.org/3/library/ssl.html#ssl.SSLContext.set_ciphers) states:
> If no cipher can be selected (because compile-time options or other configuration forbids use of all the specified ciphers), an SSLError will be raised.

`ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS` in this version of OpenSSL evaluates to `DEFAULT:!aNULL:!eNULL:!MD5:!3DES:!DES:!RC4:!IDEA:!SEED:!aDSS:!SRP:!PSK`.

However, digging into the definition of [CIPHER LIST FORMAT (v1.1.0)](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.0/man1/ciphers.html), I see a note about the `DEFAULT` cipher group alias:
> DEFAULT
The default cipher list. This is determined at compile time and is normally ALL:!COMPLEMENTOFDEFAULT:!eNULL. **When used, this must be the first cipherstring specified**.

For OpenSSL v1.1.1, [it says](https://www.openssl.org/docs/man1.1.1/man1/ciphers.html):
> The cipher list can be prefixed with the DEFAULT keyword...

Indeed, when moving the "RC4-SHA" to the end to let "DEFAULT" be first, there is no ssl.SSLError exception thrown:
```diff
-self.ssl_context.set_ciphers("RC4-SHA:" + ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS)
+self.ssl_context.set_ciphers(ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS + ":RC4-SHA")
```

I can't tell whether RC4-SHA will actually work as I don't have iLO that supports it and likely this version of Python/OpenSSL would not, but I believe is a generally more compatible way of expressing the original intention of this code.

Tested on:
> Python 3.9.0 (default, Nov 21 2020, 14:55:42)
> [Clang 12.0.0 (clang-1200.0.32.27)] on darwin
> ssl.OPENSSL_VERSION = 'OpenSSL 1.1.1h  22 Sep 2020'

If you pass "1", the split turns it into ["1"], and the join turns it back into "1", so it does what it needs to do. Can you tell me what you're actually passing as argument, and how what the old code does is wrong? Maybe then I'll understand better what you're trying to achieve.

This didn't work. With this change it fixed it.

It should be, and is valid. The old code will turn that "6" into ["6"] in the split, and then that ["6"] back into a "6" in the join. Can you run the old code in debug mode (setting the debug attribute of the ilo isntance, or passing --debug to hpilo_cli) and share the output. I have a sneaky suspicion it's not your "6" that's the problem, but something else returned by the iLO. I'd also like to see which error you're getting.
Will be able to do that next week. Can only test it at work.

I figured out what the actual issue is: the xml parser magic turns the privileges you get from the ilo into integers and not single-digit strings. So when you feed those back in, *those* are the ones that are not iterable (strings are iterable just fine). 728c085 fixes it.

Yes, this sounds like the issue I had. Was so long ago that I had trouble remembering what the actual problem was.

Thanks for fixing it.

Thanks!

Yeah, that's because the ilo's don't properly escape everything when the generate XML, so this will make them generate invalid xml. Unfortunately, the best solution here is to not use double quotes in passwords.

To anyone else bashing their head against this issue, you don't need to use a chroot or an old version of Python. Here:
```example.py
import re
import ssl

import hpilo

ilo3_context = ssl.create_default_context()

# Start with the default cipher set
ciphers = ssl._DEFAULT_CIPHERS

# Remove any explit prohibition against 3DES
ciphers = re.sub(r":!3DES", "", ciphers)

# Add on DES-CBC3-SHA, as that apears to be the 'best' cipher suite supported
# by iLO3 v1.89
ciphers = ciphers + ":DES-CBC3-SHA"

# Use the modified cipher suite list
ilo3_context.set_ciphers(ciphers)

# Allow SSLv3
ilo3_context.options &= ~ssl.OP_NO_SSLv3

# Disable any attempt at verifying the cert
ilo3_context.check_hostname = False
ilo3_context.verify_mode = ssl.CERT_NONE

iloc = hpilo.Ilo(
    "somehost", "someuser", "somepassword", timeout=5, ssl_context=ilo3_context
)

# Do stuff!
```

Works OK for me under Python 2.7.14, against G7 systems running iLO3 version 1.89. Should work under Python 3.6/3.7 as well, but I haven't tried.

@Shados This really depends on the distribution. In Debian Stretch sslv3 is deprecated and removed. You just can't use it. The reason it worked for @sharp99 is that he's using a windows 10 box where sslv3 is probably still enabled.

What worked for me (without sslv3 on debian stretch) is going to the ilo web interface > Administration > security > Encryption tab > Enforce AES/3DES Encryption > Enabled. Combining this with version 4.3 of python-hpilo fixed all issues for me.
