Awesome! Thanks for reporting bugs

This doesn't help against attacks. What would prevent the attacker who can change the .scexe files in flight from also changing firmware.conf?

And it has *very* limited value against accidents: the firmware is already signed and the iLO won't accept anything that's corrupt.

So I'll need to be convinced a lot more before accepting this idea :smile:

Good that I still have a few arguments queued up then :)

That is a valid point which is outside of the scope of this issue but also needs to be handled. There is one answer with a few implementations. Digital signatures. Linux distros do this quite well for many years now. PIP allows to upload signatures but not to check them. Git has good support for it. In your case, as you download the file on runtime, you would need to check the signature each time. GnuPG and OpenSSL come to mind.

> the firmware is already signed and the iLO won't accept anything that's corrupt.

Do you have details on that signature or is it just a checksum you can calculate yourself? Or perhaps some home-brown crypto which will break if you look at it (example [mec-tools](https://github.com/eigenmatt/mec-tools))?

The thread model I had in mind was https://downloads.hpe.com gets compromised. There is a reason software deployment uses locally verified signatures or if the origin is not able to provide signatures, use locally verified checksums.

The only new argument I see in that reply is 'what if the firmware verification is weak?'. I don't know the details of the firmware verification, but am not aware of any tools to break it or any published weaknesses, so that argument is pretty weak as well.

Linux distro signatures are bootstrapped by embedding trusted keys on the install iso. So when you trust the iso, you trust the updates. For firmware.conf, that bootstraping is a lot more difficult, and due to the firmware verification on the iso itself not quite worth it.

downloads.hpe.com getting compromised is about as likely as github.com getting compromised, so checksums in firmware.conf also don't really add anything there.

So I hope you have more arguments :)

> For firmware.conf, that bootstraping is a lot more difficult, and due to the firmware verification on the iso itself not quite worth it.

Not necessarily. Your Python module is in Debian (https://packages.debian.org/search?keywords=hpilo). When you now harden the down-streaming path too, for example, Debian by implementing #184 you are pretty far with mitigating the bootstrapping problem.

> but am not aware of any tools to break it or any published weaknesses, so that argument is pretty weak as well.

Having dealt with a few firmware formats and looking into reversing and patching one of them ([thinkpad-ec](https://github.com/hamishcoleman/thinkpad-ec/)) I have my doubts for every security feature which can not be reviewed (free access to the source code and build chain) so I would still recommend to do this additionally in python-hpilo. Also, we have no idea how good HPE is with keeping their private keys private. Their website setup does not look too well done at some parts. There is a reason why https://github.com/rootkovska/codehash.db exists. Lets bump our thread model up once more: Targeted attacks.

At least the HPE docs have some details on this:

> Authorized firmware updates – iLO firmware images are digitally signed with a 2048-bit
 private key. The boot block checks the digital signature every time iLO comes out of reset.
iLO checks the digital signature before allowing a firmware update to proceed. Remote
flashing requires login authentication and authorization, including optional two-factor
authentication.
> 
> Image Validation
> The entire image is hashed with SHA256 and signed using Hewlett Packard Enterprise’s RSA
2048-bit private key. This signature block is pre-pended to the firmware binary image.
> 
> Boot-Time Integrity Check
> At boot time, each piece has its signature validated before it is allowed to execute. Subsequent
pieces are checked by the previous ones until iLO is fully booted.

Source: https://support.hpe.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=c04530504

Sounds reasonable, at least when they keep increasing their RSA key size. 2048 bit is not really state of the art anymore.

#184 doesn't help Debian unless they actually check the signature, and nothing tells me they do. It's also only one of the distribution channels, and unfortunately people will just add any old gpg key to the apt or yum/dnf keyring that they find these days.

I'm afraid that the scaremongering about targeted attacks also doesn't work for me. Feel free to maintain a list of firmware hashes yourself, but I still don't think that the added work adds enough value to make it worth it.
@seveas When we are now talking about the extra work, one could just automate that. I addressed your other points in #184.
You might be interested: https://airbus-seclab.github.io/ilo/SSTIC2018-Slides-EN-Backdooring_your_server_through_its_BMC_the_HPE_iLO4_case-perigaud-gazet-czarny.pdf
Yeah, that's quite the SNAFU there :smile:

Thanks! I still don't quite like the argument names though, but I'll fix that up myself as I didn't comment on it earlier (and really only thought of it after rereading your updated version) :)

--ssl will become --ssl-version
--ca-file will become --ssl-ca-path and no longer automatically enables checking
--ssl-verify enables checking
--ssl-match-hostname=no disables the hostname checking

That way all ssl arguments start with --ssl

Oh bugger. This is a bit trickier as match_hostname, and some of the ssl things I also want to achieve really only work in 2.7.9 or newer, and I still support 2.4. Also, centos 7 only has 2.7.5 by now.

This may need more backwards compatibility work.

I've bitten the bullet and removed python 2.4/2.5 compatibility, which makes this somewhat easier, but also makes this pull request even harder to apply. What I think I'll do is make --ssl-verify only work on 2.7.9 and newer and die otherwise. That way we can have the best of both worlds.

927a40a is what I eventually came up with. For hpilo_cli, you can still specify the for ca path and hostname checking, but in the python code I wanted more flexibility and instead of many ssl parameters, it now accepts an ssl context to use. hpilo_cli creates such a clontext, based on the --ssl-* parameters.

As I said earlier: this is limited to 2.7.9 and newer. I've made the code error out decisively when trying to do verification on older versions.

@renard 
I have some experience dealing with iLO scripting.  Basically, you are executing two commands in one XML script that you need to put in two separate XML scripts:

The FACTORY_DEFAULTS tag causes iLO to erase its NVRAM and schedule a reboot.  Now, here is the catch:  The iLO reboot starts as soon as the XML parser sees the closing RIB_INFO tag.   Anything you add after that closing RIB_INFO tag may not execute properly because, even though the XML parser keeps executing your script, iLO behind the scenes is already preparing itself to go for a reboot and sometimes iLO reboots really quick.    

Because of this behavior, I've seen cases where some iLO settings could get corrupted.  I had this problem few years ago and I contacted HP support.  They told me to separate the XML scripts,or change the order of Tags in order to leave the one that triggers the iLO reboot to the end.

These scripts below will always work.  But, you need to wait until iLO comes back from reboot which could take ~1 minute.

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.0">
 <LOGIN PASSWORD="********" USER_LOGIN="Administrator">
  <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
    <FACTORY_DEFAULTS />
   </RIB_INFO>
 </LOGIN>
</RIBCL>
```

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.0">
 <LOGIN PASSWORD="********" USER_LOGIN="Administrator">
  <RIB_INFO MODE="write">
    <LICENSE>
      <ACTIVATE KEY="123456789ABCDEFGHIJKLMNOP" />
    </LICENSE>
  </RIB_INFO>
 </LOGIN>
</RIBCL>
```

@kryptohash again my script works nicely with versions up to 2.31 and fails with version 2.40. I use it doe years.

@renard 
I know your script used to work but, it doesn't anymore.  I had the same problem few years ago when a couple of my iLOs would end up with corrupted SNMP settings.  
My script had multiple RIB_INFO sections just like your script and, since the first section of my script was making changes to iLO network settings (MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS), all my iLOs were  rebooting at the end of the first RIB_INFO section.  
The result was a totally unpredictable behavior where some of my iLOs were getting correct SNMP settings while others were not. My iLOs were all at the same firmware level but, on different server models. Yet, they behaved differently. It was a disaster.

HP support told me to never add extra RIBCL sections after one that is known to trigger an iLO reboot. Any MOD_NETWORK_SETTINGS change will cause iLO to reboot so, will FACTORY_DEFAULTS by the way.  Making the suggested changes to my script solved my problems for good.

Basically, HP support told me that if you see this response coming from iLO:

```
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<RIBCL VERSION="2.23">
<RESPONSE
    STATUS="0x0000"
    MESSAGE='No error'
     />
<INFORM>Integrated Lights-Out will reset at the end of the script.</INFORM>
</RIBCL>
```

Any RIBCL section you see executing after this message is not guaranteed to succeed because, iLO is in the process of shutting down. In other words, iLO has began closing its doors and windows and, turning off the lights one by one in order to go for a reboot.

That may be a fix in your case, but it doesn't work in general. The iLO is supposed to escape all non-ascii characters in the xml output it generates, as that is the only way it can convey encoding of multi-byte characters. So I cannot accept that as a fix.

While I agree that it feels kinda specific I'd say that:
1. it doesn't escape characters
2. Some of these strings can be user supplied or corrupted (which it is in
this case)

My personal opinion is that it shouldn't die from this but it would be nice
if it warned...

Your patch is wrong. The data must be ascii-only, and we need to fix that as soon as we get data in, not when we feed it to the XML parser, so things like saving to files works too. The only way to do that is when decoding, and the only way to do that properly without breaking the chunked encoding is to replace non-ascii bytes with ascii characters. The questionmark seems most suitable.

You're using the API wrong. You should specify key=value parameters, e.g. `mod_dir_config(dir_grpacct6_name='....')`

Yes, when talking to the iLO via the kernel driver, no authentication is done and any password is accepted. Resetting forgotten passwords is one of the things that is made possible by this. This is a feature of the iLO itself and this cannot be changed. So if you want to manage passwords of the local iLO, you'll need to check them via the network interface I'm afraid.

```

I have updated HP ILO 4 to v2.10 still not luck..
I'm afraid that `get_cert_subject_info` is an obsolete feature, only supported by iLO2. The certificate request certainly looks valid to me though. What's the problem with it?

ummm.. well by default ILO4 add subject alternative names with hostname which my CA don't allow to sign. it requires only FQDN .. and I didn't find any way to skip SAN's from CSR using ILO GUI and python module. also when I am generating CSR it from python module CA shows that CSR is invalid. as mentioned in previous post output .. 

Is there any way to capture CSR output to proper way ?

The SAN issue is not something that is configurable I think, though if you can find an API that lets you do so, I'd love to know about it.

The formatting issue is because you don't print your response properly. Do `print(a.certificate_signing_request())` for a properly formatted CSR.
By the way, most people I know use an internal CA for signing iLO certs. As they shouldn't be visible externally anyway, a properly trusted internal CA is cheaper to use.

We are also using internal CA but It's restricted by security policies .. 
I didn't find any API in hp ilo 4 .. even newer REST API for HP ILo seems to be interface to their ssh based console over web service.. http://h20564.www2.hp.com/hpsc/doc/public/display?docId=c04423967
I've taken another look at the API, and I'm afraid you'll have to tell your CA to simply ignore the SAN's. There is no way of generating a CSR without them.

Just to add some more notes that HP  ILO4 firmware version 2.54 seems got the feature where someone can exclude or include IP for subject alternative names. By default HP ILO 2.54 version don't include IP address now, only FQDN included.
Thank you! I probably won't merge this as is but turn it into a set of smaller patches, so please be patient while I do so.

I've finally found some time to look at this again. In commit 5f6a076 I am taking an alternative approach, but with the same outcome: SAN's are added to certificates and there's retry logic for when the certificate takes a while to generate.

I also like the idea of allowing country etc. in the config file, so I added that too.

Thanks!

Thanks for spending the time doing this. There are a couple of things that I changed since then and that was the 
default_md       = sha1
to 
default_md       = sha265

Also added "localityName           = optional" to the req_policy.

The first change is to prevent errors and the second is to include the locality in the certificate so it is shown in the iLO.
Thanks, both these changes make sense, so I've added those as well and they'll be in the next version.

> > One thing that would save even more time is the generation of the
> > certificates that work with the onboard administrator. They open a new
> > window using the IP address of the iLO and not the host name. This
> > means that the certificate needs a DNS alias for the IP addess as well
> > as the unqualified host name.
> 
> That would be a nice idea. I don't generally visit iLO's this way, but
> can see that it would help in other use-cases. It would require a new
> certificate when the IP address changes though, but that's not a big
> deal.

With blade enclosures the on-board administrator is the easiest way to 
go as all 16 blades are accessible from one interface. From there we can 
click onto the individual iLOs and their remote consoles.

> There's also the problem that the iLO generates the CSR, so we have to
> mangle it to include the subjectAltName (and hope the iLO actually
> supports this.

This does work, I used hpilo_cli to generate the CSR, It seems that the 
iLO need the FQDN of the host to accept the certificate and any change 
to the network settings causes the certificate to reset to the default 
useless one. The CSR generated by the iLO includes a subjectAltName for 
the FQDN and the host name but not the IP address. So I have to add one 
when signing the request. I wasn't sure if this was possible with 
openssl but found the answer that it is possible (from TinyCA). I 
manually signed the certificate and imported it with the import 
certificate command. It worked and no more untrusted certificate.

BTW I think that HP have broken their RIBCL commands with iLO4 version 
2.10 as they now return an error saying "Error writing xml_header", I've 
a case with HP about this error message.

Kind regards
Duncan Webb

It's not `call_delayed` that returns the list of dicts, that's `get_host_data` itself. Similarly, `get_fw_version` returns a single dict, whether it's run  as part of a delayed call or not. `call_delayed` does not (and should not) change the return type of any of the called function. If it does, that is a bug.

Here's an example from the command line, the `+` makes it use `call_delayed`.:

```
$ hpilo_cli 10.1.2.3 get_fw_version
>>> pprint(my_ilo.get_fw_version())
{'firmware_date': 'Aug 26 2011',
 'firmware_version': '1.26',
 'license_type': 'iLO 3 Advanced',
 'management_processor': 'iLO3'}

$ ./hpilo_cli 10.1.2.3 get_fw_version + get_uid_status
>>> pprint(my_ilo.get_fw_version())
{'firmware_date': 'Aug 26 2011',
 'firmware_version': '1.26',
 'license_type': 'iLO 3 Advanced',
 'management_processor': 'iLO3'}
>>> print(my_ilo.get_uid_status())
OFF
```

That makes no sense to me at all. The returned items are all different, because they are returned by different functions. Treating them as one block of data is definitely not the way to approach this.

call_delayed is a shortcut to avoid some overhead in the iLO, not a way of grouping together completely unrelated data.

I'm not sure I understand your bugreport. As far as I can see, the returned dict contains all attributes of both the smbios_record node (b64_data and type) and the field tags (Family and Date). Am I overlooking something?

Thanks for the debuginfo. Unfortunately, pasting it here really mangles the output. Could you please mail me the generated file as an attachment? (dennis@kaarsemaker.net)

The debug output does show that it's definitely a bug in python-hpilo, so once I have the debug output, I will fix it asap.

It's actually a bug in the ilo3 firmware, it's misspelling `NIC_INFORMATION` as `NIC_INFOMATION`! A workaround is now in commit d1cc8fa. If this workaround works on your systems I will issue a bugfix release of python-hpilo.

Please issue a bug fix.
It works great in my environment.
Thanks a lot!

Fixed in 560cb42
I fixed this literally 8 minutes before you reported it :smile:

That's great! I can now safely re-download from pip without having to patch those lines each time.

Thank you :)
Not quite yet, the fix is not yet in a released version (it will be in the next few days, maybe even today)

It is actually a bug in the ilo firmware ~~that I _think_ locfg.pl works around (or it has the same bug, I've not actually investigated)~~ _and_ locfg.pl: In XML documents, an & needs to be escaped, the XML generated by python-hpilo does this correctly. However, the iLO firmware does not properly unescape the password field.

I'm a bit hesitant to "fix" python-hpilo, so I would recommend working around this by using a password that does not contain a & character.

I understand your point of view, you want to respect XML standards.

But as this is a bug in iLO and your code is only designed to work with iLOs (as far as I know ?), maybe would it be good to make it works ?

Regards.

It's not just about standards. Fixing this is going to require really nasty hacks to make sure it works on all supported python versions. Look at how the CDATA support in hpilo.py is implemented and think "three times uglier".
Actually, I've come up with a fairly OK way of doing this. At least it doesn't make me hide in the corner with shame. See commit 095d784, which will be in the next release.
Thanks, it's great ! Many thanks for your reactivity.

Your environment is messed up. You're using a python 3.4 stdlib with python 2.6/2.7. This will never work and is in no way related to anything python-hpilo does.

Ah, no, I need to read better :) You're using python-hpilo 2.6, not python 2.6 :)

Looking at the actual output: you're using a buggy version of the iLO firmware that uses single quotes to quote attributes. I believe python 3.4's elementtree will barf if it does that. Please upgrade the firmware of this iLO device.
Fixed in 02dca19

That was undocumented functionality that I honestly thought nobody used :smile:

It's now (b8bdf8f) part of `hpilo_cli` and documented.

Anonymysed versions are hard to parse. If you don't want the output to be publicly visible, please run the following command:

```
hpilo_cli your.ilo.ip get_embedded_health --save-response=for_dennis.txt
```

and mail the generated for_dennis.txt to dennis@kaarsemaker.net - any anonymisation you want to apply should be done only by replacing characters with the same number of characters, so do not add more characters or remove parts of the data.
Just checking if you got my email today?

I did get it, but the output is mangled too much and I can't read it back properly. Really, only overwrite characters one by one and don't add/remove more. Also make sure your editor doesn't try to "fix" newlines, as that also messed it up quite bad.

Anyway, I'm afraid the bug is not in python-hpilo, but in your expectations. AHS, and thus GET_AHS_STATUS is only supported in iLO 4. The fact that the iLO returns 'Syntax error' is a [known issue](http://seveas.github.io/python-hpilo/troubleshooting.html#syntax-error-line-0) which is annoying but impossible to fix in python-hpilo.

It is possible, but there are a few problems with it:
- It requires me to maintain that list
- The iLO version isn't always known to the code yet, so the exception handler may need to do another XML call to get that version 
- There are functions where this is a per-argument thing (mod_global_settings comes to mind)
- There may be actual genuine syntax errors due to bugs

So, so far I've not been in favor of that, and instead warned about it in the documentation. I may catch the error and reraise it with a diffetent message, such as 'Syntax error: Line #0: syntax error near "" in the line: "". You may have tried to use a feature this iLO version does not support'
I've now added that in adee97b.

Gunnar

Unfortunately there's not much you can do. The XML interface for the iLO simply is slow. There's only one optimization: store the ilo type or protocol in your asset database. That way you avoid the one request overhead for each new Ilo object to find out which protocol to use (raw for ilo/ilo2, http for ilo3/ilo4)

Actually, there is a way to speed it up: iLO interfaces accept multiple commands in one XML document. In the soon to be released python-hpilo 2.0 you can use this as follows:

```
>>> ilo = Ilo(..., delayed=True)
>>> ilo.ilo.set_vm_status('cdrom', state, True)
>>> ilo.warm_boot_server()
>>> ilo.call_delayed()
```

With a bit of reordering to minimize the amount of calls to the iLO, you should be able to speed up hpilo_boot. hpilo_facts can't be sped up as it only does one call anyway.

This should've been reported in the Juwelier project, not Jeweler. However, I will take a look at this. I switched versioning systems, and missed that bit of code.

Here's one approach I have thought of.

* decide on which will be merged into the other. I'll use merging juwelier into jeweler for the rest of this, but definitely open to discussion
* in juwelier, add a dependency on a specific version of jeweler
* remove most of code in juwelier except enough to act as a shim, ie:
```ruby
require 'jeweler'
Juwelier = Jeweler
```
* also log a warning in the top level `juwelier.rb` to say that juewlier and jeweler have been merged, and to replace `require 'juwelier'` with `require 'jeweler'` and `Juwelier` with `Jeweller`, and say that both will be released until some specific version or date in the future
* in jeweler, add the same code to suport compatibility, ie constants `Juwelier = Jeweler` and paths, with deprecation warnings. This would catch users that have updated their gem dependency, but not updated their code to use the new constants.

I will most likely merge everything back into Jeweler, since most of the users are there.

BTW, there's no way for me to change the subject line on Jeweler, which still says the code is "unmaintained". Is there a way I can be granted permission to change that line? Or maybe I should fork Jeweler into my GitHub account? Since many reference your repo, I'd prefer to do it in place.

I fixed the the repo description for now. I don't think there's a way to give someone else admin access (ie needed for description) to personal repos (just on organization repos).

I think it is possible to 'change the direction' of forks, so if you do a fresh fork of jeweler, I can file a support request to make it the primary. Links would still go to this repo, and I could replace the README with a message of what happened.

I could also make a jeweler org (not jewler since it's taken) and move the repo there and add you as an admin. The upside is that a repository should have an automatic redirect as part of it, ie links still work.
Interesting. Let me see what I need/want to do on my end. Thanks. I'll be in touch. :)

I'm not really familiar with `Rake::Task#enhance`, so can't comment on it's effectiveness here.

What I do know is that multiplatform gems are tricky with jeweler, because the gemspec only gets evaluated once, and then written to disk. At the time it's evaluated (or enhanced), it's on a specific RUBY_PLATFORM doing so. The Gem specification does not, to my knowledge, have a builtin concept of platform. You'd have to release separate gems for that.
FYI this can be worked around like: https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/issues/170#issuecomment-198682634

That name is used to determine the origin remote. I think it'll be better to separate Ruby 2.0 and RubyGems 2.0.0 compatibility fixes into 2 issues.

#### Ruby 2.0 fixes

Ruby 1.8 is soon going to be dead. If it's just Ruby 1.9 and 2.0.0-p0 that are to be supported , 
1. Replace rcov with simplecov
2. Replace ruby-debug with debugger

#### RubyGems 2.0.0 fix

If Gem::VERSION < 2.0.0 , use Gem::Builder.new(gemspec).build , else
use Gem::Package.build(gemspec)  
I'd sent a PR #237 , but that doesn't take care of backwards compatibility for RubyGems < 2.0.0
Just ran into this issue.
Me too @schneems - I thought Ruby 2.0 was ready for prime-time usage, but apparently not if major gems like this don't work...

If you never update then gems won't have a reason to support 2.0 and
beyond. The work around is to develop in 2.0.0 and switch to 1.9.3 when
releasing. Ruby Gems changed a bunch of internals that Jewler relied on.

Thank for your work @technicalpickles I hope to use Jewler with 2.0.0 in
the future.

Hey Artem, thanks for putting this together!

So, one thing I'm concerned with is having `gem (RUBY_VERSION =~ /^1\.9/ ? "simplecov" : "rcov")` be in the Gemfile (both jeweler, and newly generated projects. Part of the problem is that this conditional is evaluated at **runtime**, so if you run with 1.8, you get rcov. The other part of the problem is this then gets persisted to the gemspec as rcov. That's a problem if I release it with 1.8, and then someone using 1.9 runs `gem install jeweler --development`.

Does that make sense at all? If other people are accomplishing this, I'm not sure how they are doing it yet.

Put another way, the gem specification itself doesn't have support for dependencies per ruby version, ruby 1.8 vs 1.9. Without that, doing this 'right' gets a little hard :(

Does that make sense at all? Let me know, or if you have any other ideas on this.

That all aside, one lesser comment is that `lib/jeweler/templates/other_tasks.erb` looks like it has some changes to indent the tasks. Because they are in erb blocks, those are intentionally aligned with the left column so they get rendered without the extra space.

Hey Josh, The idea is to include rcov and simplecov together all the time and to figure out what to run during the run time. For example, I actually built jeweler with ruby 1.8 and installed it with ruby 1.9. I did not run into any issues because the run time evaluation picks up the correct path. References to rcov appear in a Gemfile and Rakefile. Gemfile is evaluated by bundler to install dependancies. Typically, independent gem repositories are maintained for ruby 1.8 and ruby 1.9. Jeweler installed with ruby 1.8 will be used with ruby 1.8 and jeweler installed with 1.9 will be used with 1.9. Now, the rcov appearance in the Rakefile. lib/jeweler/templates/other_tasks.erb is indented because because Rcov now appears in the else clause like the following: 
if RUBY_VERSION =~ /^1\.9/
  desc "Code coverage detail"
  task :simplecov do
    ENV['COVERAGE'] = "true"
    Rake::Task['spec'].execute
  end
else
  RSpec::Core::RakeTask.new(:rcov) do |spec|
    spec.pattern = 'spec/**/*_spec.rb'
    spec.rcov = true
  end
end
Evaluating Ruby version at run time is how I enable 1.8 and 1.9 support in my other projects. I am not aware of a cleaner solution, but the run time evaluation has been working for me pretty well. RVM allows me to switch between Ruby version for testing with ease. Check it out. I think you will like it. Look at it this way: the code just adds a very specific code path that is enabled for only Ruby 1.9 and rcov parts. No other variables are affected by the code, and Ruby 1.9 + rcov code path does not work in existing condition anyway.

Thanks for clarifying. I'm not sure I explained my self well though :)

There's two issues at work here:
- having a Rakefile that works correctly in 1.8 or 1.9
- carefully managing dependencies not to introduce 1.8 or 1.9-specific dependencies into gems at build time based on what you happen to be running

You covered the first issue at least, but it's the second one I'm really worried about (maybe unnecessarily?). I'll see if I can put together something that demonstrates what I'm getting at.

Before I do that, I had an idea that kind of circumvents that issue. The main thing is that it's in the development dependencies. In reality, is rcov/simplecov really a development dependency? You don't need it to run the test suite, which is what the development dependencies are for. Perhaps we can make a different grouping, like 'rake' to reflect it's only needed when running rake?

Regarding the second issue.

The way Ruby came out, we will have to live with 1.8 and 1.9-specific dependencies for some time. Jeweler already has a piece of code that deals with 1.8 / 1.9 dependencies - ruby-debug support. Dealing with Rcov/Simplecov is done in very much the same fashion.

In the case of Rcov/Simplecov, the 1.8/1.9 dependencies are external gems. Figuring out external gem dependencies is what we have the Gemfile and the bundler for. As long as the Gemfile is taken care of, bundler will figure out external dependencies. Rcov/Simplecov are test coverage tools, so we are very unlikely to see gems requesting rcov/simplecov specifically as a dependency. The gems that depend on gems dependent on rcov/simplecov is beyond my imagination. We are far more likely to see the gems dependent on gems dependent on ruby-debug.

I was thinking whether Rcov / Simplecov really belong into development dependencies too. I think Rcov / Simplecov support should be in the same way Jeweler is dealing with testing framework - --rcov --simplecov. This is a bigger discussion and a bigger rewrite, however. The impact on people upgrading Jeweler in existing projects has to be considered in this case.

An argument can be made that Rcov/Simplecov are there to help the developer figure out what parts of the code are untested and thus should belong to the development group.

I would definitely want Simplecov support in Jeweler. Simplecov is something that I use very often. The bits on how to run it and how to integrate it with RSpec are worth several hours of figuring out on your own. I thought I'd share that.

Re-discovered that bundler has support for platform-specific gems. That would work for our Gemfile stuff at least!
- http://gembundler.com/man/gemfile.5.html#PLATFORMS-platforms-

rubygems doesn't have that support itself though :-/ I think it will just make sense to exclude it as a development dependency, so rcov/simplercov don't try to install in the wrong place

Sure, you can do 

  gem 'simplecov', :platforms => :mri_19
  gem 'rcov', :platforms => :mri_18

and 

  gem 'ruby-debug19', :platforms => :mri_19
  gem 'ruby-debug', :platforms => :mri_18

It is conceptually the same as RUBY_VERSION and you still need RUBY_VERSION for the Rakefile and/or spec_helper.rb.

I think a conditional require in the bin/executable is less confusing. Running an executable just as an executable is what people used to. After all, Jewler is trying to use "#!/usr/bin/env ruby" as a shell and not the bundler.
Doing a rubygems require in the library does not make sense because the library will be required at some point somewhere before it gets executed.

The :release task does not clean the working directory before releasing the gem.

The Rakefile for qips-wfmgr does not mention any files specifically, but has a pkg/ directory which contains multiple copies of the gem: https://github.com/drbrain/qips-wfmgr/blob/master/Rakefile

Jeweler does not clean the package directory before building allowing previously released versions to be packaged into new versions, nor does it build the package from a clean directory.

Additionally, the jeweler build command does not build out of the package directory like Gem::PackageTask, but builds directly from the source directory allowing any otherwise ignored, generated files to be packaged into the gem.

See https://github.com/rubygems/rubygems/blob/master/lib/rubygems/package_task.rb#L114-122 and https://github.com/jimweirich/rake/blob/master/lib/rake/packagetask.rb#L143-155 which copy files into the package directory for staging then create the gem from a clean directory, not from whatever files the user has lying around.

By promoting using a manifest file instead of whatever the user has floating around jeweler can eliminate this problem.
Additionally, squeezer, youtube_it and tomato this problem with file sizes of 220MB, 140MB and 123MB respectively

Those are... not small gems. Yikes!

Jeweler builds a list of files from what a user has checked into git, plus anything they specifically exclude/include. In these cases, it sounds like pkg/ was actually checked into version control. That's not great in and of itself, but does lead to the problem this issue is for.

For now, the best bet I think is going to make a clean task (since it doesn't exist), and have release do that first, like you recommend.

Also worth noting that bundler uses this same style of using stuff that's in git to build, so they probably need an issue opened for something similar too.

Only one of the four jeweler-packaged gems exhibiting this problem had files in pkg/ checked in which is why I filed the ticket.

This is a little tricky. As far as I know, there's not a coverage tool that works under both. Not only that, but there's not really a way to specify that rcov is for < 1.9 and simplecov is for >= 1.9

Definitely open to suggestions here.

Yeah I don't know of one that works under both.

Why can't we just look at the ruby in the environment to see what version it is?

Failing that, I'd love to have a command line switch to control this behavior if we don't want to/can't make it automatic.

Ideally, there'd be something that works on both, or at the very least is a small shim where you could easily use it on either, but under the hood uses the platform-appropriate one.

> Why can't we just look at the ruby in the environment to see what version it is?

Possible. This would only be feasible at project generation time though.

> Failing that, I'd love to have a command line switch to control this behavior if we don't want to/can't make it automatic.

I like this idea. You'd have  control at generation time, but could also have a sane default for the platform you are on.

Would you be against having a jeweler config file that would store the state for things like this?  Using this approach we could inspect the environment at generation time, allow overrides via command line switches, and remember what was decided for future invocations.

This would get us a 'just works' set up for most users and overrides for power users.

There's already a mechanism for this :) JEWELER_OPTS is an environment variable jeweler will use, being overridden by the command line flags.

The only thing missing is to do some autodetection. We already pull things like git and github configuration in `Jeweler::Generator::Options`, so I think that'd be the place to add this.
That works pretty well with something like rvm which can set environment variables per project so that will work for my primary use case.

I don't think we should autodetect. Jeweler should act consistently for every Ruby version by default. rcov does not work for 1.9.2 - therefore I argue rcov should be optional (it is a default now). My conclusion is that we should create a switch for rcov, and potentially other coverage tools (which tend to depend on Ruby internals). The default behaviour should be to disable rcov.
I already removed rcov in #238 . Do we really need backwards compatibility of checking test coverage? I think it's enough to check it with latest ruby using coveralls or something.
Ah, I didn't understand the usage of rcov or simplecov, but rspec test will fail on old ruby if we use simplecov, is it right?

@emilsoman Yeah, I'll try to implement it. I'm interested in coveralls :)
https://coveralls.io/

Coveralls is good, but I'm not sure if it can replace rcov/simplecov, considering you need to sign up with coveralls first before you can start using it. Also, I couldn't find a coveralls API that would let you create a project. 
But it would be a cool feature to have, if you can find a way to integrate coveralls. I personally use coveralls all the time !

> I already removed rcov in #238 . Do we really need backwards compatibility of checking test coverage? 

This is a good question. I think it is probably choose something like simplecov, and if/when it drops 1.8.7, just detect that in jeweler and warn/error out that it's not available there.

The problem may be in the Gemfile. It uses `gemspec`. This loads dependencies from os.gemspec into the Gemfile. jeweler loads dependencies out of the Gemfile, and writes them out to os.gemspec on release. Circular dependency fun.

If that's the cause, the fix is to:
- remove dependencies specified in Rakefile
- move them to Gemfile
- remove `gemspec` call in Gemfile

Give that a try, and see how far it gets you please :)

I did recently learn of a bundler method called `Bundler.with_clean_env`. I haven't had a chance to try it, but should be able to wrap the call `gem install` with it.

The problem seems to be that bundler hijacks Gem::Specification.all. Without bundler this is an array (which of course supports <<). However, bundler sets it to an instance of Bundler::SpecSet which does not support <<. 
$ bundle exec ruby -e "puts Gem::Specification.all.class"
Bundler::SpecSet
$ ruby -e "puts Gem::Specification.all.class"
Array
It looks like I've been able to resolve my particular flavor of this problem (running the gem indexer) by patching ruby-1.9.2-p290/lib/ruby/site_ruby/1.9.1/rubygems/indexer.rb as follows: 
*** 124,133 ****
--- 124,134 ----

    def build_indicies
      # Marshal gemspecs are used by both modern and legacy RubyGems

      Gem::Specification.dirs = []
+     Gem::Specification.all = nil
      Gem::Specification.add_specs(*map_gems_to_specs(gem_file_list))

      build_marshal_gemspecs
      build_legacy_indicies if @build_legacy
      build_modern_indicies if @build_modern

FYI ... I just tried out slimgems (http://slimgems.github.com/), and it too resolved this problem for me.  (Don't be fooled ... it truly is a drop-in replacement.  It wasn't until I ran "gem --version" that I confirmed it was indeed installed.)
This issue was fixed in a bundler release. Please try the current release and indicate if you're still having this issue.

I just fixed it directly in my installed gem: $ mate /Users/kristianconsult/.rvm/gems/ruby-1.9.2-p136/gems/jeweler-1.6.0/lib/jeweler/commands/install_gem.rb Changed 'sh' to 'Kernel::system'. Works! PS: Would be better with a #system_exec method to wrap this IMO. 
class Jeweler
  module Commands
    class InstallGem
      def run
        system_exec "#{gem_command} install #{gemspec_helper.gem_path}"
      end

      def system_exec command
        output.puts "Executing #{command.inspect}:"
        Kernel::system(command)
      end

I abstracted the above into an Executor class with a run, print and system_exec method which the individual Command classes can then inherit from. This is an issue with Rake 0.9.0, which moved DSL methods like 'sh' out of the global Object namespace.  The methods are still available, but need to be intentionally included into classes that want to use them with `include Rake::DSL`.

The advantage of continuing to use Rake's `sh` method is that it will continue to honor rake command line flags like `--dry-run` and `--verbose`

In general, jeweler just is wrapping gemspecs. As far as I understand it, gemspecs don't allow platform-specific dependencies, so it'd be kinda hard to do.

Just to make sure I understand what you mean, could you point me at an example please?

An example would be this Gemfile:

https://github.com/eedrummer/quality-measure-engine/blob/develop/Gemfile

On line 5, I load the bson_ext gem, but only if running under MRI. Now Jeweler looks at this Gemfile and adds bson_ext as a dependency when building the gemspec. I would like to be able to tell Jeweler to ignore gems that have platform specific requirements (in this case, I want my gem to be able to run under both MRI and JRuby). So I would like to see a mechanism to deal with platform dependencies declared in the Gemfile and how they get added to the gemspec.

While bundler has support for this, I'm pretty sure that rubygems itself does not. That is to say, there's no way to tell a gemspec:

   gemspec.add_dependency 'cover_me', '>= 1.0.0.rc5', :platforms => :ruby_19

You could conditionally add this to the gemspec, but remember, this is a gemspec generated to eventually become a gem and eventually pushed to rubygems.org. If you do this from ruby 1.9, you'd end up creating the gem with that cover_me depended on _everywhere_, not just on ruby 1.9.

That's what I mean by rubygems needing to support it directly

Right now you can do it with a terrible monkey patch like this:

``` ruby
Jeweler::Tasks.new do |s|
   ...
   # load non conditional dependencies from Gemfile
   # monkey patch for conditional dependencies
   def s.to_ruby
      # see https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/issues/170
      result = super
      fail "Unexpected gemspec:#{result}" unless result.chomp!("\nend\n")
      result << "\n  s.add_dependency('jruby-pageant', ['>= 1.1.1']) if RUBY_PLATFORM == 'jruby-pageant'"
      result << "\nend\n"
      result
    end
end
```

Dependencies should be listed in the Rakefile, which is used to generate the final .gemspec file used for Gems.

You should not list dependencies in the Gemfile for a Gem. Instead of that duplication you include `gemspec` in the Gemfile, and this will alert Bundler to look for and resolve dependencies specified in the .gemspec file. See Yehuda's post on this: http://yehudakatz.com/2010/12/16/clarifying-the-roles-of-the-gemspec-and-gemfile/

Newly generated projects do include pkg/ in the .gitignore file. Not sure if you generated it recently or whatever, but you just need this line in .gitignore:

```
pkg
```

As for why restricting rake release to having a clean staging area is to basically ensure that releasing gets all the files you expect to. For example, it'd be pretty easy to forget to `git add` a new file, and release the gem without it being in version control.

Doing the steps you mention 'works just fine' like you said, so there's nothing really stopping you from doing that. Should note that release does a few other things, like makng a git tag for x.y.z.
Is there a command to bump patch, update gemspec, build and release in one step?

You should be able to combine the bump and release tasks:

```
rake version:bump:patch release
```

If you look closely at your gemspec, you will notice this lines.

```
if s.respond_to? :specification_version then
    current_version = Gem::Specification::CURRENT_SPECIFICATION_VERSION
    s.specification_version = 3

    if Gem::Version.new(Gem::VERSION) >= Gem::Version.new('1.2.0') then
```

Its because of a change in the internal of Rubygems, so it check for the rubygem version, if its an old version it adds as (add_dependency) the newer version have (add_development_dependency) and (add_runtime_dependency).

Its just compatibility stuff.

I have solved the problem of jeweler and bundler playing well together. Behold: http://github.com/dkastner/bueller

A lot of jeweler's functionality can actually be delegated to bundler. Bueller's only real job is to create gem skeletons, bump version numbers, and push out releases. You can now simply point your Gemfile to your gemspec. It also does away with the need to regenerate your gemspec all the time.

It's hard to explain. I branched off into a branch (master19). When time came to merge, i got all sorts of merge errors. I did whatever the articles and FAQ's wanted me to, and synced the branches, but each time i merge, the same errors come up. So now I've abandoned master, and want to release and created gems from master19.

But rake checks out master and creates a gem from there.

I'd suggest looking at rebasing master19 off of master, instead of a merge. That way, you can replay commits one at a time, and have to resolve conflicts one at a time, rather than a ton at once.

If that fails, in your case, I think I would basically abandon master by removing it (ie `git branch -D master` ), and then recreate it off of master19 (ie `git checkout -b master master19`), and then force push the new master to replace the one on github (`git push --force origin master`). This is a bit destructive though, such that if you have any forks, they will have troubles rebasing off your new master.

The issue with jeweler not being on the path is more likely an issue at the OS level rather than anything. See this bug for some discussion on dealing with this on ubuntu: https://bugs.launchpad.net/ubuntu/+source/ruby1.8/+bug/145267

You probably want to add /var/lib/gems/1.8/bin to your path, instead of the jeweler specific one. One thing this does is wrap up the jeweler executable in rubygems' tender embrace, making sure that rubygems is require along with any dependencies before executing for real.

As for not getting having the git gem installed, that is pretty weird. It's listed as a dependency, and rubygems should be pulling it down. What version are you using, ie `gem --version`?

Its widely acknowledged that the "future" seems to be new hosted web services like rdoc.info and yardoc.org. However I just wanted to point out why those sites aren't really the first choice for everyone.

1)
rdoc.info is allright if you've documented everything in Yard. But there are many big / older projects (and new ones!) that are still written in rdoc. And yard doesnt care to support very well at all. So all the rdoc formatting, etc gets all screwed up on rdoc.info. So its better to use hanna templates and push them out to our gh-pages automatically with jeweler. This is also as rubyforge is now getting defunct.

2)
Theres seems to be enough of us who aren't really that overwhelmed with the look and feel of the new Yard template on those sites. Thankfully Loren has written a plugin system into yard. So theres actually people (including myself) who are writing yard plugins which overlay onto that original template with a different layout, improved look and feel, etc.

Not to mention Loren's own plugins for documenting additional things like the rspec tests, etc. However these new yard plugins simply cant be applied to either of the websites rdoc.info or yardoc.org, which run in a restricted fashion. (They wont allow running of arbitrary ruby code on server-side for security reasons). 

But its fine if we can do local generation + gh-pages. Id just like to make this more convenient in jeweler.

Looks like the grancher.rb file is plenty small enough to be included within jeweler. That would mean no extra gem dependency.

http://judofyr.github.com/grancher/

Hi,

Just been looking at your latest code. I like that you have switched to using Thor::Group.
However, I would recommend shifting both the classes Jeweler and Jeweler::Generator to modules. Then have a class Jeweler::Generator::Builder for the builder generator and other classes inside the Generator module for other generators, such as for versioning etc. Each of these classes, such as Builder should inherit from Thor::Group and include Thor::Actions. I see no reason to keep the old Options class except for temporary use while migrating to the new Thor form ;)
I also recommend using the octopi gem for accessing the Github v2 API, fx for use when creating a new github repo.

It's about baby steps. Each step has been towards a cleaner design without breaking existing functionality. Don't worry, it'll get there.

The feedback is appreciated, but like I said, mailing list or IRC or another issue is probably more appropriate.

I have the same issue with Ruby 1.8.6. It started after I upgraded Jeweler from 1.4.0 to 1.0.1.

Like Codesponge, I added a `require`, which fixed it. I decided to add it to the top of `lib/jeweler/generator.rb`, which seemed like a better place than in the bin.

I did a quick check, and it appears that `FileUtils` at some point became part of the core, whereas it used to be part of the standard library. My hypothesis is that this change happened in 1.8.7, and thus the module is being required by default in 1.8.7 but not in 1.8.6. I could be wrong--I didn't spend a lot of time diagnosing this.

I think it would be worth including this fix in the next release. I'm guessing everyone on 1.8.6 is going to have this problem. I know it might not be a huge priority to support older Ruby versions, but 1.8.6 still has a wide install base, and the fix is really simple. (Provided, of course, that it doesn't break things in 1.8.7!)

ruby 1.8.7 (2010-01-10 patchlevel 249) [i686-darwin9]

$ gem list
jeweler (1.4.0)
```
I have yet to be able to reproduce this. Considering it doesn't hurt existing users who it doesn't work, I added the require of fileutils to the top.

@behrangsa it's intentional that setting `gem.version` makes the version tasks go away. Generally when you use this, you are keeping it in some constant, so it wouldn't necessarily know how to bump it if you set it this way.

@rgarner wasn't able to reproduce with your repo :( I tested with ruby 1.9.2 and a few variations of rubygems.

There is some good news though. I was able to reproduce on a blank repo. I recently upgraded rubygems all the way up to 1.8.5. I suspect this started coming up between 1.3.7 and 1.8.5.

I was able to track down where this is happening in the code, but... not so much why :(

It's coming up when the gemspec on disk is read into memory and parsed for saneness, ie [right here](https://github.com/technicalpickles/jeweler/blob/master/lib/jeweler/gemspec_helper.rb#L51). For whatever reason, when the version is getting set from the gemspec on disk, the version is nil, which is where the `undefined method`prerelease?' for nil:NilClass`comes in. You can clearly see`s.version` is not in in the gemspec.

Another boggling piece of this is that when you do `rake gemspec`, this does a write then a validate, and this works fine. If you run `rake gemspec:validate` directly, it fails.

I checked on @ahamid's suggestion about prereleases, but it seems to be happening regardless of the combination of 0.0.0 and prereleases

---

That all said, I'm kind of considering ditching the way validation happens currently. But first, a history lesson:

Back when GitHub did rubygems hosting, one of the biggest pain points was having the gem fail to build due to invalid gemspecs, and there were plenty of interesting ways of accidentally having that happen. One of the earliest goals of jeweler was to make it easier to cope with this, and so it did the same eval that GitHub did, and it was great.

Fast forward to today, and well, GitHub doesn't host rubygems anymore, and for rubygems.org, you end up building them yourself. If there's a problem building it, you'll see it pretty quickly :)

Given all that, removing this particular validation seems like a good idea. I'll try to get that out next jeweler hacksession I sit down for, and will likely release it as 1.7.x.

I've checked this thread and source code, then I may find something.

The main problem is the difference between `gemspec` and `gemspec:validate`.
`gemspec:validate` depends on `gemspec:generate` about gemspec_helper. `gemspec:generate` set version string in `gemspec_helper.spec.version` and `gemspec:validate` uses this variable. It seems to be the reason of different behavior.

Another small problem is `jeweler` command doesn't insert `gem.version` into default Rakefile.

I think resolving each single problem will fix this issue, but I'll try to fix both of them when I have time.

`rake build` used to read the on-disk gemspec, so it had to regenerate the gemspec to the most recent gem built. This has since changed though, but it still relied on the gemspec task to regenerate the on-disk gemspec.

So, I'm not opposed to seeing bundler support (in fact, would like to see it).

However, I don't particularly like it placing gems into `bin/`. I just feel like that'd have some annoyances, like you'd have to start git ignoring stuff in bin, except for things that you'd want distributed, in addition to specifying them in gem.executables.

Perhaps bundler can be configured where it places the binaries?

This is possible.

```
# Specify where gem executables should be copied to.
#
# This is an optional setting.
# The default is: bin
bin_path "my/executables"
```

That's good. So, I'd think it's make sense to have them in bin/vendor, vendor/bin, something along those lines. That mean...
- The generator creates Gemfile
- Gemfile species a path for the executables that not in bin
- gitignores this path
yeah. ill fork and implement.

I went with the following:

`--bundler` flag to the generator

use `./gbin` for the bundled gem path

add both `./vendor` and `./gbin` to .gitignore.

Yes, sorry, I don't know why I didn't do a copy/paste...

I think you could support both versions in the generator (by rescuing the LoadError exception and retrying with the other path).

For the problem of already generated projets, I think it's really another bug: one should be able to update its jeweler-generated Rakefile to get modifications of the template, or even add new targets (for example someone should be able to add the reek target if the project was generated without it).

Doing a begin/rescue within a begin/rescue to support both requires seems a little messy.

Considering this is a generator, I think it'd make sense to go with the most recent version, and just make sure the error message tells you to install the specific version that starts using the different task require.
A non-jeweler specific fix would be to patch reek to put back the old file, and do a deprecation warning.

I'm happy fix Reek so that the old file would exist again in v1.2.8 and requires the new file. But there will still be a few versions of Reek that don't have the file, which would mean that those folks would need to update their Reek gem to latest anyway; in which case they could also update their Jeweler gem too, and thereby acquire a version of Jeweler that requires the latest Reek rake task.

So in the end I'm not convinced that changing Reek back would make sense. For example, if I deprecate the old file, at some point this problem will occur again when I want to EOL that old file in some later release of Reek. Please advise?

(BTW, I had no idea Jeweler uses Reek -- cool! I wish I had known sooner, so that I wouldn't have broken the rake dependency.)
So, one thing 1.5.0 will bring is bundler support. That will help here, because you could just add a specific reek version to Gemfile, and you'd be good. Let's say that fixes the problem :)

Thor uses the name of the class as namespace, so you should run the gemspec task as:

thor default:gemspec

thor :gemspec

I've looked into this a bit. After looking at rubygems and gemcutter there isn't much jeweler needs to do other then set the env variable [RUBYGEMS_HOST](http://github.com/qrush/rubygems/blob/gemcutter/lib/rubygems/command.rb#L373). 

`gem push` (which jeweler uses for releasing to gemcutter) _should_ just work then.

As for the server, you can run your own gemcutter server. It is easy to setup. I am also debating whether or not it is worthwhile to write a light weight, database free, gemcutter api compatible gem server. Again, that _should_ allow for client tools like jeweler to just work.

I do this all the time now.. it works just fine.

 GEMCUTTER_URL=https://gemcutter.myinternal.domain gem push ./pkg/supergem.gem
If that works, you should be able to do `GEMCUTTER_URL="blah" rake gemcutter:release` as well.

You generally want to wait until the last possible second to bump the version, ie right before the release.

If you bump the version, and at some point generate the gemspec, it will have the new version. If you happen to commit and push this, github will rebuild the gem. Then you decide to release finally. Unfortunately, the gem would have already been built, meaning the tagged release and the gem's source would not be in sync.

This is mainly why it does force a commit.

So, I'm kind of out of ideas. My best bet probably is to try to reprduce the problem on windows. Because of unrelated reasons, I recently had to install windows on a spare laptop, so I can try to reproduce...

Tracked this down. git gem issues command `git config '--global' '--list'` where parameters are quoted with `'` and windows cannot handle these. Using double quotes fixes this. lib/git/lib.rb line 713

```
def escape(s)
  '"' + s.to_s.gsub('"', '\"') + '"'
end
```
It works, thanks!

I'm not really inclined to add this just for the sake of compatibility with other libraries' rake tasks.

If someone runs `rake gem`, and see there's not a task, it's just a matter of `rake -T` to see what should be run to use the gem.

Additionally, if a gem author wishes it, they are easily able to add it to their own `gem` task that does just as you are looking for.
So, advantages: compatibility with the other 'n' gem generators; drawbacks: none. interesting...

I know. Crazy, right?

The short version is I don't think it's a significant enough advantage to really be bothered with. The much longer version...

There used to be a lot more aliases around for a bunch of the rake tasks. In the end, I decided to prune them down so that there was just a canonical way of doing them. So, not wanting to add extra tasks to be compatible with other gem management libraries is kind of in the same vain.

In addition, if I were to want to provide such task-level compatibility, I'd probably want to take a lot closer look at what tasks these other libraries provide. Do they all really have a 'gem' task which builds the gem? Are there any tasks they have that are of interest that jeweler doesn't? Are there any task name overlaps which aren't the same, or that behave different? And so on. For example, hoe has `rake release VERSION=1.0.1`. That's kinda different than the way jeweler works

I can confirm I had the same issue with an existing project.  Installing the updated jeweler gem broke my existing rakefile as it could no longer see the rubyforge tasks and was unable to publish.  Adding the following to my rakefile fixed the issue:

```
Jeweler::RubyforgeTasks.new do |rubyforge|
  rubyforge.doc_task = "rdoc"
end
```

I'm not super familiar with UTF-8 in general, so I'm not sure I can fix this myself.

I've found some notes about doing a File.open to write as utf-8, but it seems to be Ruby 1.9 specific.

Hm, I’m using Ruby 1.9 and UTF-8 in my summary field and both the gemspec file and the resulting gem’s metadata contain the proper UTF-8 strings – i.e., this bug does not manifest itself in my case.

Markus: I tried your name in my gem and it worked. Did you specify the right Ruby file encoding (my Rakefile’s first line is ‘# encoding: UTF-8’)?

BTW: \303\274 is the proper binary representation of UTF-8 ü:

```
>> "Markus Hüberman" == "Markus H\303\274berman"
=> true
```
It would make sense for the _generated_ Rakefile to add `# encoding: UTF-8` as its first line.  This is harmless in Ruby 1.8 but very important in Ruby 1.9 for consistency.

It probably writes like that under 1.8 because it looks like it uses .inspect to dump the string back out. 1.8 isn't aware about UTF-8, it just sees special chars and escapes them. 1.9 is more intelligent about UTF-8 so it'll output as expected.
To fix this if you apply the following string: # encoding: utf-8 with the hash at the top of each generated gemspec file it should resolve the issue. I could be wrong but this works for me locally
sorry just realised SFEley also wrote this. +1 on this working :-)

$KCODE = "U"

**rubyforge:release failing because rubyforge_project in config is not used**

Most of the time, your project is your gem name, so for most cases, it’s cool.

Just update your Rakefile to point where you want to be uploading too.

Because it’s not a jeweler task, it doesn’t actually have access to the gemspec, and hence, the rubyforge_project.

So, I did want to keep it flexible about where you upload files too (maybe you want root to be rdoc, maybe not), and I didn’t want to introduce any non-gemspec configuration, so I left this as hardcoded (but generated at least).

 by Josh Nichols

This has been addressed by the new Jeweler::RubyforgeTasks that's in 1.0. Just add a line like this to your Rakefile:

```
Jeweler::RubyforgeTasks.new
```

processor_ids: {}

to

processor_ids:

Yeah, I just didn't want to break any of the other configurations. This project has turned into a game of [whack a mole](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VoP1E9J4jpg) with all the user-contributed configuration, so it's really easy to accidentally break someone's setup when making what seems to be a tiny and benign change. That said, if you want to submit a PR for that, I'd be open to it.

Long term, I would love to be able to migrate folks off this app and onto GitHub Actions, so everyone can have exactly what they want, and can configure things independently at the repo (or organization) level. See #90

Came here to open up an issue about this and found this issue - so let me add my thoughts here. The current behavior is the right behavior - for single commit PRs, Github uses the commit's title and not the PR title (why Github has this quirk is an open issue I think). So by blocking it, you're ensuring that your commits in default branch are always semantic.

That said, I wish this worked beyond `isVanillaConfig` case.

A GitHub Action would be to slow. You often times want to change the pull request title and then merge a few seconds after that. A GitHub Action will take at least 20s. Ideally it would work within 2s

> A GitHub Action would be to slow. You often times want to change the pull request title and then merge a few seconds after that. A GitHub Action will take at least 20s. Ideally it would work within 2s

So `amannn/action-semantic-pull-request` is a node action and it's much faster. I see it finish within 5s most of the time. You can still spend a little time waiting for a runner to become available if you have lot of jobs going on at the same time but for most of folks, that should be a non-issue.
This should be auto-deployed to production soon.
Thanks, @zeke! 🎉

@zeke 
We are using the GitHub app/action with this config:

```
# Always validate the PR title, and ignore the commits
titleOnly: true
# Always validate all commits, and ignore the PR title
commitsOnly: false
# Always validate the PR title AND all the commits
titleAndCommits: false
# Require at least one commit to be valid
# this is only relevant when using commitsOnly: true or titleAndCommits: true,
# which validate all commits by default
anyCommit: false
# Allow use of Merge commits (eg on github: "Merge branch 'master' into feature/ride-unicorns")
# this is only relevant when using commitsOnly: true (or titleAndCommits: true)
allowMergeCommits: true
# Allow use of Revert commits (eg on github: "Revert "feat: ride unicorns"")
# this is only relevant when using commitsOnly: true (or titleAndCommits: true)
allowRevertCommits: true
```

We also use `dependabot`, which creates single-commit PRs, and we use GitHub "Squash and Merge".  With these dependabot single-commit PRs, we're seeing them be failed by the `semantic-pull-requests` check, even though the commit message and PR title are semantic (see screen shot).  Could you explain why this is happening, and suggest a solution for this?

Thanks.

Hi @don-hover,

I don't have time to dig into this specific case right now, but I can offer some suggestions:

1. Try stripping down your config file to nothing, then incrementally adding the configuration you need, like the custom dependabot scope. External contributors have added new configuration options over the years, and now the codebase is a bit of a mess and bugs are more likely to come up as your config file grows. I still use this app, but without any custom configuration.
2. If that doesn't work, try forking this repo and creating a test that reproduces your failure scenario. We can work together from there to fix it.
3. Fork the repo, make any changes you need, host it yourself, and create a new GitHub App.
4. Use a GitHub Action like https://github.com/amannn/action-semantic-pull-request instead of this app.

I hope that helps.

> Are the custom types only applicable to commits, but not PRs?

I'm not actually sure, as I didn't implement that feature and I don't use any custom types in my projects. You may have to jump into the code here to figure out how it's working. If PR titles are not being supported, I will happily accept a pull request that fixes that.

So after testing once again, I noticed that after merging `.github/semantic.yml` to master, then every next PR will have the custom types. By default, only the pre-defined ones work, which is a weird behavior.

Ah yes that's [expected behavior](https://probot.github.io/api/latest/classes/context.html) from Probot:

> For security reasons, configuration is only loaded from the repository's default branch, changes made in pull requests from different branches or forks are ignored.

Thanks for following up. 👍🏼

Hey folks 👋 

TLDR:

- Sorry about that.
- Will try to stabilize more in the future.
- Consider migrating to a [GitHub Actions workflow](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/issues/90) for your own safety.

My apologies for the recent downtime. It was caused by a [merged pull request](https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/pull/94/files) with some breaking changes that were not caught by the existing test suite.

I am pleased that this service is valuable to people and excited to see that so many developers are embracing semantic workflows for releasing software. On the flip side, this is a side project of mine, and the growing adoption of this service has pulled me away from my regular work.

The app was initially designed for use within the @electron org with a specific use case in mind: **Does this pull request have enough semantic information to trigger a semantic-release when squashed?** When this was the app's only behavior, things were more stable. But as it has grown in popularity, members of the community have come forth with slightly different use cases, and they've contributed changes that have made the application logic much more difficult to understand and maintain. I've made an effort to welcome these contributions and accommodate people's needs, but in hindsight maybe I should have been a bit more discerning about the contributions I've accepted.

Going forward, I will make an effort to be more careful and scrutinous in evaluating new pull requests, bearing in mind that breaking the service could affect many users.

I am also investigating GitHub Actions powered alternatives to this GitHub App. The distinct advantage of Actions in this case is that each user (you) has autonomous control over the configuration of their workflow, and are not beholden to some unknown third party (i.e. me) who may accidentally break things when the service goes down. There's an unfolding discussion about Actions-based alternatives here: https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/issues/90

Thanks for reading, and keep up the good work. ✨ 🤖 ✨

To anyone affected by the outage mentioned in this issue, you may be happy to know that there's a (no longer buggy) GitHub Action that might suit your needs better: https://github.com/zeke/semantic-pull-requests/pull/111 -- switching could mean one less service dependency for you and your app! 🍰

I was unhappy with the pre-existing GitHub Actions( weird emoji support) and I looked a bit into this. I ended up just using an `if` on the PR title. It's not pretty, but it works.

As it'll be a while until I open-source the project using these actions, here's the relevant code:

```yaml
name: Conformance

on:
  pull_request:
    types: [opened, synchronize, edited]

...

steps:
  - name: PR title is valid
    if: >
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '📦 ') ||
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '🐛 ') ||
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '👌 ') ||
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '🚀 ') ||
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '‼️ ') ||
      startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '⬆️ ')
    run: |
      echo 'Title checks passed'

  - name: PR title is invalid
    if: >
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '📦 ') &&
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '🐛 ') &&
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '👌 ') &&
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '🚀 ') &&
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '‼️ ') &&
      !startsWith(github.event.pull_request.title, '⬆️ ')
    run: |
      echo 'Pull request title is not valid. See .github/PULL_REQUEST_TEMPLATE/pull_request_template.md for details'
      exit 1
```

At one point I was even commenting back on the PR for more visibility, but I thought that was a bit much:
```yaml
- name: Comment for PR title conformance
  if: failure()
  uses: peter-evans/create-or-update-comment@v1
  with:
    issue-number: ${{tojson(github.event.number)}}
    body: |
      Please ensure your PR title starts with an icon:
        📦 New things / new features / new docs
        🐛 Fix existing thing / bug fixes
        👌 Improve something / refactor
        🚀 Release / ship / deploy
        ‼️ Breaking changes / user involvement requires / manual delivery steps
        ⬆️ Dependency updates / tooling bumps

      PR titles should be, in order of importance:
        - imperative( _add_ instead of _added_)
        - explicit
        - short

      Examples of PR titles:
        📦 Add yaml support
        📦 Add Firefox browser tests
        📦 Tutorial for API Interface
        📦 ADR: Use Terraform for IaC
        📦 Add automated CHANGELOG
        🐛 Fix conversion failure for Italian
        🐛 Stop panic on baldy formatted input
        👌 Improve handling of JPEG files
        👌 Link to PRs in CHANGELOG
        👌 Refactor event routing
        ‼️ Change API response codes
        ⬆️ Bump json from v5 to v6
```

FWIW, an app works out much better for multiple projects. It's faster than GH actions, doesn't eat up actions runtime quota, easier to configure and so on. There's more you can do with GH actions but doing so again and again across projects becomes tedious after a while.

The work I did in this field is [`github-tools`](https://github.com/unifiedjs/github-tools#readme) and [`npm-tools`](https://github.com/unifiedjs/npm-tools#readme), which is about all the metadata around repos, packages, and orgs: the thing that are not checked in. Okay, it seems there are few more thigns that need to be updated, but quick fix for now can be to make a check if there is results in the `value` / `commits`.

Like

```js
  const { error, value: commits } = validate(message)

  if (error) {
    console.error(error)
    return false
  }
  if (commits.length === 0) {
    return false
  }
```

***

edit: The problem is that `value` is an empty array, which is because of few reasons: 

- `check()` is filtering out `null` and `undefined`
  + like `.filter((x: PossibleCommit) => x !== null || x !== undefined)`
- probably other reasons

Another way to workaround is to directly use `validateCommit` which will use the `checkCommit` instead of `check` from which mainly comes the problem.

Hey @ccangialose! Thanks for submitting this PR and apologies for the delay reviewing it.

I will start off by saying that I am willing to merge this PR to support your organization's use case. You've added new tests and the existing tests continue to pass, so it appears this new functionality will work.

I will add though that I think the configuration options for this service should be reconfigured somehow. Currently we have these options: `titleOnly`, `commitsOnly`, `titleAndCommits`, and soon `anyCommit`. When considering all the possible combinations in which these options can be used, it's a bit confusing and seems inviting to bugs in the code.

Thinking out loud, what if we moved to something like this:

Prop | Allowable Values | Default
--- | --- | ---
`validateTitle` | `true` or `false` | `undefined`
`validateCommits` | `'all'` or `'any'` or `false` | `undefined`

In the case where both `validateTitle` and `validateCommits` are `undefined`, then the default behavior would be to require at least one semantic commit OR a semantic title.

Hi @zeke! Thank you for the review.

I agree, and I think your proposed reconfiguration is a great, clean solution. If you would like, I would happily put some time into attempting to implement it and contribute something that provides greater benefit to the project.

Thanks for your willingness to help out, @ccangialose!

One thing that would be tricky about making these changes would be there are already lots of users of this service, and if we change the config, then their integrations will no longer work as expected... We'd probably need to update this bot to open issues on repos when their `semantic.yml` configuration is outdated.

Maybe we should ship this PR to unblock your organization, and then follow up on a refactor in a separate PR. Does that sound good?
@zeke That sounds great! Thank you.

I totally disagree with that. Specs are not to be easy for newcomers, they are up there for combining and standardizing the things among the biggest part of a community - in this case, us the developers which have experience and we are not newcomers. Also, currently it's pretty clear and easy enough - type, scope, subject, body.

And yes, I agree and understand that most of us don't use the body when committing, even more we don't put scope most of the time. But breaking change is something that should be carefully done and hard to do, that's one point why it's uppercased.

If we are going to do it simple why just don't remove everything and just make the spec to handle only the header part. Specific attention to writing the `BREAKING CHANGE` part is the best thing of the spec. Not to mention that `!` is a single character and no that easy to be seen.

> paves the way to a future where people don't have to write BREAKING CHANGE in the commit body to signal a breaking change

👋 Thanks for reporting. You're right about the current behavior. Here's what we have now:

default behavior: validate title or at least one commit is semantic
`titleOnly: true`: Always validate the PR title, and ignore the commits
`commitsOnly: true`: Always validate all commits, and ignore the PR title

For what reason would you want to validate both the title and all commits? I'm not against it, but wondering about your use case.

+1 on this. 

Our use case is the following: GitHub doesn't let you choose a default squash commit message. Squashing a pull request with one commit would use that commit’s message, but squashing a pull request with more than one commit will use the pull request’s title for the commit message. We want to make sure that every single external contributor PR in our repo gets merged with a valid squash commit message so checking both would be beneficial for us. 

Ideally we would be able to check the squash commit message only (so PR title for multiple commits, commit for single commit).
@CecileRobertMichon would only allowing "squash merging" on the repo work for your case?

@zeke not exactly. We already only allow squash merging. The issue is that I can't control how many commits are in a pull request and GitHub is inconsistent when squash merging commits. If there is a single commit, the commit message comes from the commit. If there are multiple commits, the commit message comes from the PR title. So checking only the commits or only the title is not sufficient since either may be used at squash time.

Got it. There's an open issue about squashing single-commit PRs: https://github.com/probot/semantic-pull-requests/issues/17

I am pretty busy right now, but would happily accept and ship a PR that addresses this.

Lying in bed this evening putting my kids to sleep, pondering the great mysteries of the universe, it came to me! I think the bot stopped working for private repositories when https://github.com/probot/semantic-pull-requests/pull/30 landed, which introduced support for configuration of the bot using a `.github/semantic.yml` file. The GitHub App's token doesn't include a scope for reading repository contents. For public repos this change had no negative effects because unauthenticated API requests for files still work, but for private repos those requests are likely now failing and causing the bot to fall over.

@paszkowskiDamian based on your comment above, the timing sounds about right, as #30 landed on November 28.

One way to work around this would be to preserve the current minimally-invasive token scope by disallowing `semantic.yml` configuration for private repos, but that seems weird to have a different behavior between public and private repos. 🤔 

I think the best option now is to update the GitHub app to require read access to repository contents. Are folks willing to give this bot read access to their private repo contents, though?

Hey. Great to know 😊

About the "how" it is a good question: on our side we are accepting "github" plugins (developed by github directly) but we are taking care to all others...especially if they are requiring file access.
The reason is simply related to security: we don't know what plugin maintainers do with the retrieved data (are they logging somewhere plugin runtime information?). 

Anyway, take the decision you want for your plugin...we will then check on our side if the security département allow the activation :)
