Thanks for submitting this, @guyfedwards.

Since this PR is introducing configuration to the project, I think it would be useful to consider other ways people might want to configure the bot so we have a naming scheme that is flexible from the start.

A few configurations come to mind:

- title or at least one commit is semantic (current behavior)
- all commits are semantic
- title is semantic
- title and all commits are semantic

Also, let me play devil's advocate for a moment and suggest that maybe we can make the bot accomodate all use cases without requiring configuration. In #29, I suggested:

> One approach would be to make the bot check what types of merging are allowed on the repo (rebase/squash/merge), and if squash is the only allowed merge type, then the requirements would change and the PR title would then have to be semantic.

@guyfedwards would this approach work you? If not, why not?

Just want to clarify: I don't intend to block progress here. Happy to merge this and ship it, but want to consider our options carefully first.

Thanks for the quick response @zeke 

Agreed about the improved naming scheme, are you suggesting having them as string options for a `mergeType: 'title_commit'` style property in the config? Or a set of various boolean flags like: 
```
semanticCommits: boolean
semancticTitle: boolean
```
? 

I'm not sure how viable the inferred settings would be but my main reasoning against that approach would be that it moves the configuration out of the code and into Github settings. 
Now every time I want to use my setup in a new repo, I must change Github settings as well as install the bot, instead of just copying the `.github/semantic.yml` file which is both version controlled and it would seem shareable/extendable.

I am also keen to see the outcome of https://github.com/probot/probot-config/issues/23 as I don't like the idea of forcing users to include a config file if they wish to use the default settings as this seems unnecessary, but I'm sure this is just my misunderstanding or missing some config.

What about something like this:

```yml
validate: title
validate: allCommits
validate: anyCommit
```

or


The second format above is simpler, but doesn't account for the current behavior of "title OR any commit"...

hmm yea that's a tough one. The second is much cleaner but I think the first is more flexible and ends up being clearer than having `boolean`/`string` options mixed in the second.


Thanks for opening this issue, @guyfedwards. The current behavior of the bot is not to police every commit message and PR title, but to ensure that the PR contains enough semantic information (either in the PR title or the commits) to determine if a semantic version bump is needed. In the PR you've linked to, the PR title is not semantic, but the commits are. That's enough to satisfy the bot (and tools like `semantic-release`). Does that makes sense?

Hi @grv87. Yep, that's intended behavior, but thanks for opening the issue anyway.

The goal of this bot is not to police commits, but to encourage gathering the minimum amount of semantic information needed to trigger a release. When using tools like `semantic-release`, a single semantic commit is all it takes, and it doesn't matter whether they're all semantic.

The projects using this bot (namely all repos in the @electron org) have a general practice of squashing pull requests into a single commit. In this scenario, NONE of the commits have to be semantic, as the Pull Request title will become the commit message when squashed.

Does that clarify things? I'm open to ideas on how to make it more intuitive.

Yes, it does. Thank you!

Maybe this could be mentioned in documentation.
Thanks! 🍦

i may not have explained well enough above, but my use of a `wip` commit type is to signify that the change is ready to go to `master`, but doesnt yet qualify as a `feat` or `fix`. the wip bot [treats it the other way around](https://github.com/greenkeeper-keeper/hapi-greenkeeper-keeper/pull/436#issuecomment-370653846) where `wip` is meant to mean that the commit is meant to be squashed or rebased away before merging. its not the only place i've come across the conflicting meanings, so i've considered using something other than `wip` but haven't yet since it still makes sense to my teams in the context of projects preferring continuous integration. i'm looking forward to the wip bot being [configurable](https://github.com/wip/app/issues/96) so that i can use it in a way that doesnt worry about commit messages.

while that detail is probably less important to my request above, it does highlight the benefit of flexibility that could be added by looking at a commitlint config. different users could assign whatever meaning they intend through such a config, without the bot being directly aware. you certainly wouldnt want to include options for this bot directly to enable all the variations of deviation from conventional-commits that people may want, but using an existing config file might make including the flexibility more reasonable.

Ah I see. Unfortunately you can't actually denote a breaking change using the PR title, as the `BREAKING CHANGE` string needs to be in the Body™ of one of the commits, not in the first line of the commit (aka the Subject™). This is how the [Conventional Commits spec](https://www.conventionalcommits.org/) is defined.

I'm open to ideas on how to make this easier, whether that means changes to this bot or proposing a change to the Conventional Commits spec to which this bot adheres.
Related: https://github.com/probot/semantic-pull-requests/issues/51
I don't see how #51 is related to that. The linked `#336` simply just doesn't follow the spec.
#51 is related because it's about the process for signaling a breaking change.

I'm going down a rabbit hole here and remembering why `simple-commit-message` seemed like a good choice at the time.

https://github.com/kentcdodds/validate-commit-msg looks pretty much perfect and fits all the needs of our project:

```
> validate_commit_msg('fix: something')
true
> validate_commit_msg('build: something')
true
> validate_commit_msg('build(foo/bar): something')
true
```

However that project is archived, and it is recommended to use `commitlint` instead. But `commitlint` seems to be designed primarily for use as a CLI, and trying to use it programmatically means navigating through a maze of numerous subpackages in the @commitlint scope...

I like the idea of following the spec outlined at https://conventionalcommits.org, so we have a common understanding of what we're adhering to.

I hate to say it, but maybe we should just hardcode this list for now?

```
[
  'build',
  'ci',
  'chore',
  'docs',
  'feat',
  'fix',
  'perf',
  'refactor',
  'revert',
  'style',
  'test'
]
```
Resolved by #16

Further info:

https://developer.github.com/v3/pulls/#merge-a-pull-request-merge-button API can be used to explicitly set the `merge_method` to `squash`. This would work if the bot was merging the PRs. 
Humans could summon the bot to merge by either adding a label (e.g. `merge`) or with a comment (e.g. `/merge`). Note that in the case of using a comment, the bot would have to check that the commenter actually has permission to merge the PR.

Also, an edge case for squash commits (via @francisfuzz):

> I was reminded of something I learned about how we treat squash merges recently and would like to share it here in the case it hasn’t been considered by the Electron team.
>
> Squashing a pull request with one commit would use that commit’s message, but squashing a pull request with more than one commit will use the pull request’s title for the commit message.
This issue was mostly resolved by #19; the unresolved part is now #17
The maintainers of this repository would appreciate it if you could provide more information.
